She requests this loan for her husband's business. He works in the construction field, carrying out work for engineers who are awarded projects by the State. He works from Monday to Saturday from 8am to 6pm. He says that he works with the help of 10 workers who he pays every week. He has three years in the business. 

He requires this loan to purchase some wheelbarrows and other necessary tools for his work. She has been with her communal bank for three loan cycles and she likes it because it is through these loans that she is able to contribute something for the home. 

Her dream is to finish building her house as it is currently under construction.

loans.use: to purchase wheelbarrows and tools.

loans.name: María Monserrate

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se  reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Valroc. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños que son reconocidos en todo el país y por la calidez de su gente amable y trabajadora.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora María, tiene 32 años, está separada pero de esa relación tiene tres hijos de 14, 13 y 4 años de edad, en la actualidad está embarazada 9 meses de su cuarto hijo, los mayores están en colegio y el menor este año empezó la escuela.

Ella tiene una tienda de comestibles en su casa, vende todo tipo de productos como arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, etc. Trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, sus  hijos le ayudan en su trabajo cuando están desocupados, los productos para surtir su tienda los compra en Portoviejo aunque la mayoría los recibe en su local. Nos cuenta que lleva 10 años con su tienda y que es su medio para sacar adelante a sus hijos ahora que se encuentra sola.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y otros productos de primera necesidad. Está en el Banco Comunal hace dos años y le gusta por la seriedad de sus compañeras y de la institución.
 
Sus metas son seguir adelante en su negocio y que su tienda crezca cada día más.
texts.en:
The members of the communal bank named Valroc meets in the city of Rocafuerte every two weeks. This place is known for its delicious sweets prepared by the locals that are known throughout the country and for the warmth of the kind and hardworking people.

Here we meet Maria. She is 32 years old, separated, but from that relationship she has three children, aged 14, 13, and 4 years old. She is 9 months pregnant with her fourth child. The eldest children are in school and the youngest started school this year.

She has a convenience store in her house, selling all types of products such as rice, sugar, cooking oils, detergents, etc. She works every day from 6am to 8pm and sometimes even later than that. Her children help her with the work when they have spare time. She buys products to stock her store in Portoviejo although the majority of them are delivered to her store. She says that she has 10 years in the business and this is how she is able to support her children, especially now that she is alone.

This loan will be used to stock her store and so she will purchase rice, sugar, cooking oil, detergents, canned goods and other basic needs products. She has been with her communal bank for two years and she enjoys partaking for the seriousness of her colleagues and of the organization. 

Her goal is to keep her business going and to make her store grow more every day.

loans.use: to purchase rice, sugar, cooking oils, detergents, canned goods and other basic needs products.

loans.name: Luz

texts.es: Luz tiene 53 años, vive con sus 4 hijos y su esposo en su casa que es propia. Hace más D. 19 años que se dedica en la venta D. golosinas, en donD. tiene un stand móvil en la puerta D. un colegio, ahí los niños, quienes son sus clientes, siempre acuden para consumir algún producto o bebida gasificada. Su horario D. trabajo es durante el recreo, así como la salida D. los alumnos. Sus hijos le dan su apoyo, cando tiene que dejar el puesto para irse al mercado mayorista y adquirir más mercadería para implementar su negocio. Su deseo es mejorar su stand e implementar su puesto D. golosinas. Es su crédito número 13 con MFP, durante este tiempo con su grupo considera a cada uno D. sus integrantes sus amigas y con las que pueD. contar porque tiene confianza. Este crédito lo invertirá en la compra D. más mercadería en dulces al por mayor.
texts.en: Luz is 53 years old and she lives with her 4 children and her husband in a house that is their own. She has been selling sweets for more than 19 years. She has a cart and she takes it to the door of the school where the children, her clients, always come looking for some snack or soft drink. Her work schedule is during recess time and when school is let out. Her children help her when she needs to leave the stand to go to the wholesale markets to acquire more merchandise for her business. Her wish is to improve her stand and to supply her sweets business. This is her 13th loan with MFP (Kiva Field Partner) and today she considers each one of the members to be her friends that she can depend on because they have her trust. This loan will be used to purchase more merchandise in wholesale.

loans.use: to purchase sweets in wholesale.

loans.name: Hortencia Margarita

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se  reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Valroc. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños que son reconocidos en todo el país y por la calidez de su gente amable y trabajadora.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Hortensia, tiene 62 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen nueve  hijos todos mayores de edad, el menor de ellos vive en su casa y estudia en universidad, con ella también vive una hija que es madre soltera junto a su hijo pequeño. Su esposo es comerciante.

Ella junto a su esposo tiene un negocio de cibercafé y cabinas telefónicas en el que también vende bocadillos de picar, sodas, jugos de frutas y otras golosinas. Trabajan todos los días desde las 8h000 hasta las 21h00, en este negocio también ofrecen el servicio de tipeado de trabajos en computadora y venta y recargas de teléfonos móviles. Nos cuenta que llevan 15 años dedicada a esta actividad. 

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su negocio con bocadillos, colas, golosinas y para pagar la mensualidad del internet que es lo más ganancias les deja. Está en el Banco Comunal casi desde el inicio y le gusta por la seriedad de la institución ya que el crédito siempre les llega cuando lo necesitan.
 
Sus metas son seguir adelante en su negocio y que este crezca cada día más.
texts.en:
The members of the communal bank named Valroc meets in the city of Rocafuerte every two weeks. This place is known for its delicious sweets prepared by the locals that are known throughout the country and for the warmth of the kind and hardworking people.

Here we meet Hortensia. She is 62 years old, married, and she has nine children from her relationship, all of whom are grown. The youngest of her children lives at home and he is in university. She also lives with one of her daughters and her young son as she is a single mother. Her husband is a merchant.

She and her husband have an internet cafe and telephone booths and they also sell snacks, soft drinks, fruit juices, and other snacks. They work every day from 8am to 9pm. They offer typing services and they sell cell phones and prepaid cell phone cards. She says that they have 15 years in the business. 

This loan will be used to supply her business with snacks, cola drinks, and sweets and to pay for the monthly internet access fees which are what yields the most earnings. She has been with the communal bank almost from its beginning and she enjoys partaking for the seriousness of the organization. The loan is always ready when they need it. 

Her goals are to keep up her business and to make it grow more every day.

loans.use: to purchase snacks, soft drinks, sweets and to pay the monthly internet access fee.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to carry out maintenance repairs to his car, to buy spare parts, and to also purchase sheep.

loans.name: Gabriela

texts.es:
La señora Gabriela tiene ya más de tres años dedicándose a la venta de productos de belleza por catalogo y de joyería femenina.
Al negocio le está haciendo falta mas variedad de mercancía como es perfumes para mujer y hombres, también desea vender ropa y zapatos, pero no cuenta con el dinero necesario para invertir en el negocio.
Solicita el préstamo para poder comprar la mercancía y así tener más inventario en su negocio e ingreso. 
Planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias que obtiene de su negocio, ya que su esposo el señor Juan Antonio se encargara de los gastos familiares, con el ingreso que obtiene de su trabajo.
texts.en:
For over three years, Gabriela has been making a living by selling beauty products and jewelry through a catalog. Currently, her business lacks variety when it comes to items such as perfume for men and women. Gabriela would also like to sell clothing and shoes but does not have the funds necessary to purchase the inventory.

Gabriela is seeking a loan in order to purchase additional merchandise which will permit her to have a wider range of products and to increase her income. To repay the loan, Gabriela will use the earnings from her business, given that her husband, Juan Antonio, will take care of the household expenses with the income he receives from his job.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for the business

loans.name: José De Dios

texts.es:
A la vivienda del señor José De Dios le esta haciendo falta la barda alrededor de su casa ya que chocaron y se la destruyeron. 
Esta solicitando un préstamo para poder comprar el material que esta necesitando y pagarle a la persona que se encargara de realizar la mejora que necesita. 
Desea la seguridad y el bien estar de su familia.
Planea pagar el crédito con el ingreso que obtiene de su trabajo como repartidor de mercancía de una compañía de piquería.
texts.en:
Jose de Dios' house does not have a surrounding wall following an car accident that destroyed it. 

He requests a loan to be able to purchase construction material that he needs and to hire a person to carry out the project. 

He wants to provide his family with safety and well-being. 

He plans on repaying the loan with the income that he obtains from his work as a delivery person for a snack food business.

loans.use: to build a wall around his house.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda P., 58, aims for a completeness in life. Erlinda completed elementary education and is married to Agustin, who is into business just like her. They have been blessed with three children who are now working. Together, they live in Brgy. Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines.
Erlinda has sold dry goods and assorted merchandise for quite some time now. She buys her merchandise in bulk and resells it at piecemeal rates. Among the products she sells are household cleaning materials, electrical and hardware items, batteries, needles and threads, and the like. Serving her local community, she earns an estimated net income of around 11,000 PHP per month.
To help her continue to operate her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She intends to use this loan to buy more merchandise to add to her current product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Not having an entirely complete supply of merchandise as compared to other wholesalers, sometimes Erlinda would like to give up, but she refuses to give in to the pressure. Instead, she works hard for ways to improve her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God. *All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise to add to her current inventory.

loans.name: Baruela

texts.en:
This is Baruela D. R., 60, a resident of Brgy. Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Samson, an overseas Filipino worker, and is the mother of four children.  Baruela is a high school graduate who manages her own micro-business to help her husband earn a living.

Baruela operates a variety store which, in the Philippines, is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal in the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP’s-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Baruela's store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. Baruela earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her store, Baruela is requesting a 21,000 PHP loan.  She plans to use it to buy more products such as groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Baruela dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.
 
*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her variety store.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
This is Nenita C., 48, a resident of Malaria, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Nelson C. who is helping her in managing her micro business.

Nenita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP’s-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail rates. She earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her variety store, she is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages so as to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Nenita dreams that her business will become bigger and she will be able to enjoy life with good health and abundance. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God as she studies. 

*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her variety store.

loans.name: 3 De Septiembre (Portoviejo) Group

texts.es:
En  el sector conocido como Los Ángeles en la parroquia Colon  de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúnen  cada quince días las socias  del Banco Comunal 3 de Septiembre. Las mismas que se dedican a diversas actividades tales como la agricultura, el comercio en general, prestan servicios como cabinas telefónicas y salones de belleza. Unieron sus esfuerzos para poder acceder a los beneficios que presta la Fundación Espoir, este es su primer crédito y esperan seguir por mucho tiempo en el Banco Comunal.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Nelly S., tiene 28 años y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijos de 10 y de 2 años de vedad, la mayor  estudia en escuela. El marido es guardia de seguridad.

Ella es una muy buena ama de casa que se dedica a la venta de  productos para el hogar (planchas, licuadoras, ventiladores, camas, etc.), de zapatos y zapatillas por catalogo. Ella enseña la revista donde están todos estos artículos y sus clientes deciden que es lo que quieren comprar, luego ella realiza los pedidos y entrega los productos de acuerdo al número que tengan sus clientes, realiza los cobros cada ocho días. Nos cuenta que lleva 4 años realizando esta labor y que le va muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar planchas, licuadoras, ventiladores, camas, sandalias y zapatos. Este es su primer ciclo en el Banco Comunal.
 
Su sueño es tener su casa bien construida ya que la que tiene es de caña.
texts.en:
In the sector known as Los Angeles in the community of Colon of the city of Portoviejo the members of the communal bank named "3 de Septiembre" meet every two weeks. They have various types of businesses including agriculture, general store, and services such as telephone booths and beauty salons. They joined their efforts to have the ability to access loans from Fundacion Espoir (Kiva Field Partner). This is their first loan and they hope to keep their communal bank going for a long time.

Here we meet Mrs. Nelly S.. She is 28 years old, married common-law, and she has two children, aged 10 and 2 years old. The eldest is in school. Her husband is a security guard.

She is a very good house wife and she sells various household products (irons, blenders, fans, beds, etc) and she also sells shoes by catalogue. She displays the catalogue where these articles are pictured and her clients decide what it is they would like to purchase. She then places her orders and she later delivers the products according to the number assigned to her clients. She takes payments every week. She says that she has 4 years in the business and it has been very successful. 

This loan will be used to purchase irons, blenders, fans, beds, sandals, and shoes. This is her first loan cycle with her communal bank,

Her dream is to have a well built house, as her current house is made of canes.

loans.use: to purchase irons, blenders, fans, beds, sandals and shoes.

loans.name: Boldbaatar

texts.en:
Mr. Boldbaatar D. is 43 years old. He lives with his wife and 3 children in Kherlen city of Dornod aimag, the far eastern province of Mongolia. This is situated 750 kilometers away from the capital city. 

Boldbaatar's family owns a plot of land and a small family house. Boldbaatar's wife runs a metalware business, selling utensils and tools made from metal, in the market. Boldbaatar himself owns a motorcycle and runs a delivery business. His three children go to the local secondary school. The loan that Mr.Boldbaatar is requesting will be used to buy different metal products for his wife's business. They will purchase metal sheets, utensils and tools to sell. A small portion of the loan will be used to service Boldbaatar's motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy different metal products, for his wife's business, such as metal sheets, utensils and tools to sell. A  small amount of the funds will be used to service his motorcycle.

loans.name: Munhbat

texts.en:
Munhbat is 28 years old and lives with his wife and only daughter in a house in Sansar of Bayanzurh district, Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife works at G-Mobile, Telecommunication Company. 

Munhbat manages a souvenir trading business at Sunday Plaza, one of the largest and crowded trading centers in Ulaanbaatar city. He has been managing his business for 3 years and has gained much experience. He is planning to expand his business in the future. He is a generous man who says, "I am planning to rent one more stall in order to increase my business sales." He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more souvenirs for his business inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more souvenirs for inventory.

loans.name: Lennie

texts.en:
Lennie is married, with 2 children in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Lennie is 30 years old.  She has a ready-to-wear business in the Philippines. Lennie requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more ready-to-wear clothing to sell.

Lennie has been in this business for 2 years.  In the future, Lennie would like to do some home improvements.

loans.use: to purchase more ready-to-wear clothing to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Purevdorj

texts.en:
Mr.Purevdorj is 26 years old. He lives with his wife and 2 sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Purevdorj owns a plot of land and he is planning to build a house on it in the future. Currently they live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. 

Purevdorj’s wife works in the “Blue sky” cashmere factory as an operator of a weaving machine. Purevdorj is truck driver with a private company and his job has a seasonal character. Therefore, on his free-of-work time, Purevdorj runs a taxi business. His taxi operation brings extra income to the family. He wants to replace his old family car for a newer one and he needs some money to top up his savings. The loan will be used to renew this old family car which he will use as a taxi.

loans.use: To renew his old family car to a newer one. He uses the car for his taxi business.

loans.name: Apolinaria

texts.en:
Apolinaria is a married woman with one child in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur.  Apolinaria is 51 years old.  She has an egg business in the Philippines. Apolinaria requested a PHP 13,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy a larger stock of eggs to sell in her stall.

Apolinaria has been in the business for 16 years.  In the future, Apolinaria would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more eggs to sell in her stall

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: I Wayan

texts.en:
I Wayan S., 38 years old, is married and has two children. He works as a pig farmer earning 1,300,000 Indonesian rupiah (IDR) every three months. He raises pigs for pork rolls that are sold after being kept for three months. He applied for a loan of 1,500,000 IDR to buy super quality pig food, because this time he already has 10 pigs. I Wayan S. plans to save his profit to be used for the future of his children.

I Wayan S. lives with his wife and two children. Both of his children are still attending school. He spends 25,000 IDR for the cost of the kitchen every day. This is his first loan with MUK.

loans.use: to buy super quality pig food.

loans.name: Nazaria

texts.en:
Nazaria works hard to support her family. She is widowed, and has a decoration sales business.  Nazaria has been in the business for 10 years, and also earns additional income from making flower vases.

Nazaria requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional decorations to sell.  In the future, Nazaria would like to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional decorations sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Srun

texts.en: Srun S., 57, resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known as one of Pre-Angkorean Temples. S. produces traditional baskets and sells fruit, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 78 on food and USD 90 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more fruit and baskets to resell. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more fruit and baskets to resell.

loans.name: Sot

texts.en: Sot S. is 53 years old and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for itsf Pre-Angkorean temples. S. sells vegetables and meat, earning an income of $2.60 per day. Her husband is a traditional musician, earning an income of $2.30 per day. Each month, the family has to spend $83 on food and $90 on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan for $1,000 to purchase more meat and vegetables to expand her current business. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to purchase more meat and vegetables

loans.name: Neneta

texts.en:
Neneta is married, with 5 children, four of whom are in school.. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur.  Neneta is 45 years old.  She has a fish vending business.  Neneta requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish to sell in their community.

Neneta has been in this business for 18 years.  In the future, Neneta would like to do some house improvements and send her kids to college.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is a 62-year-old widow with six children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She has a ready-to-wear clothing/shoes business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for five years. 

Rosalina requested a 10,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy products and stocks of clothing to sell.

 In the future, Rosalina would like to save enough money to provide financial security for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of clothing to sell.

loans.name: Khurelbaatar

texts.en:
Mr. Khurelbaatar is 31 years old. He lives with his wife, three children, and mother-in-law in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife looks after the kids. Khurelbaatar has been running a taxi business since 2008, and it is the family's only source of income.

In 2008, Khurelbaatar's family suffered a big loss when the ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent) in which they were living burned down completely. The cause of the fire was bad electrical wiring. They currently live crowded into Khurelbaatar's mother-in-law's ger. Since the disaster, Mr. Khurelbaatar has been saving money to buy a plot of land and a ger. At the moment, he needs some extra money to fulfill his plan.

Our institution's "green loan" product supports families in buying traditional Mongolian nomadic felt-covered tents made from sheep's wool. The loan Khurelbaatar is requesting will be used to supplement his payment in buying a plot of land and a ger.

loans.use: to purchase a plot of land and a ger (a traditional nomadic tent) for his family.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 31 years old and married with one child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She has a cosmetics business in the Philippines, and has been. in this business for two years.

She requested a 10,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy more stocks of perfumes and cosmetics to sell.  In the future, Rose would like to do some home improvements.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of perfumes and cosmetics to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Soa

texts.en: Soa V., age 50, resides in Takeo Province in Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorian Temples. V. is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of 3.60 USD per day. His wife produces cow ties and raises chickens and ducks, earning an income of 2.50 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 75 USD on food and 90 USD on other necessary expenses. V. is requesting a loan of 700 USD to purchase a new motorbike to operate his business more efficiently. This will be his third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike to operate his business more efficiently.

loans.name: Ma. Vangie

texts.en:
Ma. Vangie is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a ready-to-wear clothing business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for fourteen years. She earns more income from a sari-sari (variety) store.

She is borrowing 16,000 PHP through NWTF to buy more stocks of clothing to sell in her ready-to-wear clothing business.

Ma. Vangie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to do some business improvements and send her kid to college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of clothing to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem S., age 44, resides in Takeo Province in Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorian Temples. S. sells cow ties and fish grillers, earning an income of 3.30 USD per day. His wife is an assistant at a local hospital, earning an income of 1.60 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 75 USD on food and 90 USD on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of 700 USD to purchase more cow ties to resell. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more cow ties to resell.

loans.name: Eulalia

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Eulalia works hard to support her family.

She has a ready-to-wear clothing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling frozen foods.  She is borrowing 10,000 PHP through NWTF to buy different items like pants, shorts, blouses, etc. to sell in her stall.

Eulalia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 6 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college and to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy different clothing items to sell in her stall.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has an abaca weaving business in the Philippines. (Abaca, a strong fiber from the leafstalk of the banana plant, is also called Manila hemp and is used in textiles and papermaking.)  She has been in this business for ten years. She earns more income from raising pigs.

She is borrowing 15,000 PHP through NWTF to buy raw materials for her abaca weaving business. Anita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for abaca weaving.

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en: Sourn N., age 50, resides in Takeo Province in Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorian Temples. N. is a farmer, earning an income of 1.00 USD per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of 3.50 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 25 USD on food and 48 USD on other necessary expenses. N. is requesting a loan of 400 USD to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for the children to commute to work.

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Emilia is 61 years old and has a common-law husband and 2 children.  Emilia works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell in her stall.

Emilia has borrowed and repaid 6 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 10 years and also earns an income from raising pigs.  Emilia aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell in her stall

loans.name: Enkhtuvshin

texts.en:
Mrs.Enkhtuvshin is a 43 year old tailor. She lives with her husband and 2 children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband works as an electrician. They own a plot of land and recently built a family house. The roofing on their house still needs to be finished. 

Mrs.Enkhtuvshin runs a tailoring business. She rents a small workshop in the basement of the building. She makes and fixes clothes and dresses by customers' orders. The loan she is requesting will be used to complete the roofing at her house and a small portion of the loan will be used to buy some textile materials for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To buy wood planks, rockwool insulation, roof tiles to complete the roofing on her house. A portion of the loan will be used to buy textile (materials) for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Awen Indah Group

texts.en: The nine member Awen Indah Group, led by Ni Komang A., age 20, received a first loan from MUK totaling 13,500,000 Indonesian rupiah (IDR). Each member gets 1,500,000. Ni Komang A. used this loan to buy three piglets at 300,000 IDR per pig, and used the rest to repair the barn. Before getting a loan, she was raising pigs and making a profit of 200,000 to 250,000 IDR. She hopes that with this loan her business will increase and she will make more profit.

loans.use: to buy three piglets.

loans.name: Magelene

texts.en:
Magelene is 42 years old and married, with one child.  Magelene works hard to provide for her family. She runs a Sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 100,00 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell, like sardines, groceries, etc., in her sari-sari store.

Magelene has borrowed and repaid 2 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the Sari-sari store for 4 years and also earns an income from food vending.  Magelene aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell

loans.name: Rosebella

texts.en:
As a married parent of 5 children, Rosebella works hard to support her family.  She has a firewood business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from sari-sari store.  Rosebella is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to  buy more stock of firewood to sell.

Rosebella has been sustaining her business activities through her past 6 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to repair and renovate her home and to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to buy more stock of firewood to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is 57 years old and married, with 5 children. Marina works very hard to provide for them.  She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell, like oil, groceries, etc., in her sari-sari store.

Marina has been in this business for 4 years and sells a variety of items, such as candies, cigarettes, curls, eggs, salt, etc..  In the future, Marina would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem lives in an industrial city of Pakistan known as Faisalabad. She has been living in the area of Dhanona in a two-room brick house for the past 25 years. She is 35 years old, married to M. A. and has two sons and two daughters. None of the children has attended school (except the eldest one, who studied 'til 10th) due to the poor financial conditions of Naseem and her family. Now that son operates a timber selling business while the others stay at home. Her son’s business is going well because most of his clients live in areas where gas is not available and they use wood for cooking food. 

Naseem's husband runs a construction supplies business. He makes deals with different construction companies and individuals and makes profit by fulfilling their orders. 

Naseem is a housewife. She spends most of her time at home and carries out her household responsibilities. She has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her son's business. With the loan, he will buy timber in bulk quantity that will help him fulfill the demand of his clients and make extra income. Naseem is hopeful that this investment will be a productive one for her son. She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Naseem.

loans.use: to buy timber for a timber selling business.

loans.name: Jaya Usaha Baluk Group

texts.en: Ni Nengah T., 41, became chairman of the group Jaya Usaha Baluk, which has 10 members. She got a loan of 1,500,000 Indonesian rupiah (IDR) to buy four piglets. This type of pig is used for roasting and the price is 250,000 IDR per piglet. The pigs are fed for three months and ready to sell for 400,000 IDR. She chose this type of pig because they do not require special food and that can reduce costs. She has a dream to renovate her house with the profits gained from this business.

loans.use: to buy four pigs.

loans.name: Farzana's Group

texts.en:
Farzana sews clothes for neighborhood clients. She learnt this art from her mother, and now she is making full use of it to bear the financial burden of the family with her husband. She is very skillful and receives regular orders every month. She is also a very responsible housewife who manages her household work very well. Her husband's name is A., and he provides transport services to his passengers by driving a local three-wheeled vehicle called an auto rickshaw. Farzana has given birth to two daughters. Both of them are studying by attending a local school. 

Farzana has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her sewing business. She will buy a new sewing machine with the loan that will help her sew clothes in a shorter period of time and fulfill her orders on time to earn more profit. Farzana is hoping that by investing loan money in her own business, she will be able to receive more orders every month and improve her income. She has been in this profession for the past 10 years. 

Farzana is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. She is a resident of Dhanona which is a small housing colony located in Faisalabad. Faisalabad is Pakistan’s third largest city and well known for its textile industry.

In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Farzana.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine for a sewing business.

loans.name: Ha's Group

texts.en:
Ha T. N. is 38 years old with 2 children. She lives in a Mai Hien commune whick has good conditions for farming.  She focuses on growing rice in  paddies of 4,500 square meters, and raising chickens for eggs. Everyday she sells eggs at retail to achieve a daily income. Participating in our program since 2006, she is always a good re-payer and uses loans efficiently and effectively in expanding her farming. Now she needs to have a  loan of 8,066,000 Vietnamese dong to buy food for chickens


   Thin T. N.  is 43 years old with 2 children. She is running a small business that make tofu and sell in  local market. She need to have a loan of 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong to buy  bean as material
   Can T. N.  is 38 years old with 3 children. She has a  grocery  shop in Centre market. She needs to have a loan of 7,630,000  Vietnamese dong to  buy more new  products  to attract customers
  Xuan T. N. is 37 years olds with 1 children. She is managing a  shop that provide internet service. She needs to have a loan of 7,630,000 Vietnamese dong  use  for upgrade internet system
  Khanh T. N. is  45  years old with two children. She is raising 200 chickens for eggs. She needs to have a loan of 6,322,000 Vietnamese dong to buy food for them

loans.use: to buy food for chickens

loans.name: Mandakh

texts.en:
Mr.Mandakh is 52 years old. He lives with his wife and son in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His two eldest daughters study at University in Hong Kong and his youngest son studies in the local secondary school. His wife works as cleaner. 

Mandakh used to work for the Mongolian railroad company as an engine-man for his entire life. In 2009 he had to leave his job on a disability pension. He has to pay for his 2 daughters' University fees each year. Therefore, on top of his disability pension, he earns some extra money by running a taxi business, using his family car. He is asking for a loan to buy some spare parts and to do proper service to his car which he uses as a taxi.

loans.use: To buy some spare parts and to do proper service to his car, which he uses as a taxi.

loans.name: Trang

texts.en: Trang Thi Thuy N., 27 years old, is a businesswoman who is married with 2 children. She has a shop where she sells draft beer and soft drinks. She opened the shop 4 years ago right after she received her first loan. Her shop is continually growing and it creates a considerable income for her to manage her living expenditures. In the summer, her shop will be crowded with customers. Trang Thi Thuy N. wants to borrow 8,502,000 VND to to make more seating room by buying more sets of tables and chairs.

loans.use: to buy more sets of tables and chairs

loans.name: Saiful

texts.en: Saipul A. works as a fisherman on the island of Menjangan in the western part of Bali. Saipul A. is a diver. At this time he is using his own boat, but still relies on the wind to go to sea and the results are not optimal. He borrowed Rp. 10,000,000 at MUK to buy a boat engine so he could explore the wider marine and get maximum results. He already has a customer that will buy the fish. Saiful A. lives off the coast. He spends Rp. 30 000 per day for meals and Rp. 120,000 for electricity.

loans.use: To buy a boat engine

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim T.  N., 37 years old, is married with 2 children who attend high school. She has a shop where she sells draft beer and soft drinks. She also provides sugar cane water, having bought a machine to make it when she received her first loan. Her shop is continually growing and it creates a considerable income for her to manage her living expenditures. In the summer, her shop will be crowded with customers. Kim T.  N. wants to borrow 7,630,000 VND to make more seating by buying more sets of table and chairs.

loans.use: to buy more sets of tables and chairs.

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Hoa T. N. is 38 years old with 2 children. She lives in the hamlet of Dai bi and joined our credit program in 2007. When she received her first loan in the amount of 1,900,000 VND, she invested in opening a small restaurant  serving breakfast items such as noodles, bread and rice soup. Her business has continually grown and created a stable income for her to manage her family's living expenses. Throughout her participation in our credit program, Hoa T. N. has always repaid her loans well. She wants to take out a loan of 8,502,000 VND to buy some cooking appliances.

loans.use: to buy some cooking appliances.

loans.name: Batkhuyag

texts.en:
Mr.Batkhuyag is 53 years old. He lives with his wife and three of his children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has 5 children, but the two eldest ones are married and live separately. Bathuyag has a job contract with a tourist company. He owns a minivan, which he uses to transport tourists to the countryside. 

Batkhuyag owns a plot of land and recently he completed the building of a family house. Now he is working on his garden. He likes growing different plants and fruits in his garden. He is applying for a loan to buy sea buck thorn trees to plant in his garden. These trees give yellow berries that are rich in vitamin C and they can stand the very cold winter. A lots of people grow and harvest sea buck thorn berries and sell them to pharmaceutical companies for money. For 1 kilo of raw berries, on the vegetable market, the cost is around 6000 Mongolian tugriks (around 5USD).

loans.use: To buy sea buckthorn trees and to plant them on his land to harvest the berries.

loans.name: Robina's Group

texts.en:
Robina lives in the third largest city of Pakistan called Faisalabad. It is known for its textile industry and is located in Punjab, Pakistan. She has been living there with her family in the area of Dhanona in a two-room brick house for the past 20 years. She is married to M. A. who has a construction supplies business. His shop is located in the market where he offers different construction materials such as cement, bricks and sands to his clients. Robina has given birth to six children. Her eldest son helps his father in his business and the others stay at home. Robina couldn’t provide her children with an education due to poor financial conditions. She herself is a housewife who prefers to stay at home and do her household work. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who will put more construction supplies in his shop and expand. He has been operating this business for the past 10 years and Robina is confident that an investment will help him make better profits. She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Robina.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies to sell

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia lives in Faislabad, which is an industrial city in Pakistan known for its textile industry. She has been living there in a four-room brick house with her family for the past 30 years. She is a housewife and does her household work by staying at home.  Her husband's name is A. M. and he is 55 years old. He owns a small piece of land where he grows different seasonal crops. After cultivating, he sells them for a good profit. 

Razia has given birth to two sons and a daughter. Her daughter is an embroidery expert and her sons drive their rickshaws and provide transport services to the passengers. They all contribute to their family financially from their earnings. 

Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who will buy fertilizers, seeds and pesticides for his agriculture business. Her husband has been doing this business for the past 25 years and Razia is very confident that his business will grow further after investing the loan money into it. She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Razia.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda is 42 years old and married with 4 children.

Merlinda works hard to provide for her family.  She runs a business that buys and sells bananas in the Philippines and requested a 26,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy different varieties of bananas to sell.

Merlinda has borrowed and paid 9 loans from NWTF before this loan.  She has been running this business for 8 years and also earns an income from being an Avon dealer.

Merlinda aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy different varieties of banana to sell

loans.name: Bernardita

texts.en:
As a widowed parent of 1 child, Bernadita is a very hard  working entrepreneur.  Bernadita is 65 years old. 

Bernadita has a seaweed culture business in the Philippines.  Bernadita requested a 27,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy raw materials for her seaweed culture (goso).
 
Bernadita has been in this business for 19 years.  In the future, Bernadita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her seaweed business

loans.name: Haidee

texts.en: Haidee is 44 years old and married with 3 children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Haidee has a fishing business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy fishing gear and equipment. Haidee has been in this business for 13 years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and equipment.

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
As a married parent of 4 children, Conchita is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Conchita is 56 years old and has one child who is in school.

Conchita has a fishing business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy a new engine for her fishing boat. Conchita has been in this business for 6 years. In the future, she would like to save enough to secure her family's future.

loans.use: To purchase a new engine for her fishing boat.

loans.name: Gemalyn

texts.en:
Gemalyn is a married woman from the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She has 3 children aged 20, 18 and 17.

Gemalyn is engaged in farming. She primarily grows rice crops to sell. Gemalyn works hard to provide for her family. She needs seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs for her rice farm. She requested a loan to purchase the supplies required for her farming needs.

Gemalyn hopes for her family's living conditions to improve and for her children to finish college and to find decent jobs.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim lives in Faisalabad, which is Pakistan’s third largest city and known for its textile industry. She has been living there in a two-room brick house with her family in the area of Mariam abad for the past 10 years. She is married to R. M. and has two children. Both of them are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education. She is a very caring lady who makes the utmost effort to provide comfort to her family by fulfilling their needs.

Her husband is involved in a scrap business. His shop is located in the market and he supplies scrap to different scrap dealers and factories. He is the only earning person in the family. That’s why it is very necessary for him to improve his business conditions. Shamim has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. He will purchase scrap like plastic bottles, used papers etc. Shamim hopes that the loan investment will bring positive financial changes to her husband’s business and improve the living standard of her family. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In her previous loan year, she proved herself as a responsible client by paying the installments on time and by attending every meeting. 

Note:“In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Shamim.

loans.use: To buy scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita B. is from the village of Kuguita, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 45 years old. Mercedita is married and has 4 school-aged children. Mercedita owns & operates a furniture making business, making & selling general household bamboo made furniture like sofa & tables to local businesses and community members. Mercedita has been engaged in her business for over 18 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mercedita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Mercedita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional raw materials to expand the product offerings. Mercedita is requesting a new loan of 23000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials like bamboo, nails & varnishing paints. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Mercedita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase raw materials like bamboo, nails & varnish paints.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 46 years old and is a married woman. She has a 10-year-old child.

Jocelyn is a farmer working in the municipality of Santo Niño in South Cotabato Province. She primarily grows rice crops and sells her harvest to the market. Jocelyn works hard to sustain her child's education and to improve her family's living conditions.

Jocelyn is planning to use this loan to purchase rice seeds, fertilizer, and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase rice seeds, fertilizer, and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert S. is from the village of Panaguitas in the municipality of Kibawe in Bukidnon Province. Robert is 22 years old, and he is single. To make a living, Robert owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, junk foods, biscuits, and detergents in the local community. Robert has been engaged in his business for over two years, and he earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Robert joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Robert has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Robert is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, beverages, and biscuits. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Robert from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Mariam's Group

texts.en:
Mariam has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s welding business. Through the loan, he will buy a new welding machine that will help him weld spare parts and other iron items belonging to his clients. His current welding machine is not producing quality work and that’s why Mariam applied for a loan to buy a new welding machine. 

She belongs to Faisalabad which is an industrial city of Pakistan famous for its textile industry. She lives there in a 2-room brick house in the area of Mariam Abad. She moved here some years ago with her family. Her husband is the only earning person in the family and works very hard to bear the financial expenses of his family. 

Mariam has a son and a daughter. Both of them are illiterate due to financial constraints. Her husband is well known for his good customer dealings and for the quality of services he offers to his clients.  He has been operating this business for the past 6 years and Mariam is hopeful that an investment will help him further improve his business. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In previous loan year, she established a good credit record and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Mariam.

loans.use: To buy a new welding machine for her husband's welding business.

Roquella owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, junk foods, shampoo, soap & beverages in the local community. Roquella has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 12000 PHP a month for these activities.

loans.name: Lenida

texts.en:
Lenida is a married woman and mother to 4 kids. Her eldest child is 22 years old.

Lenida earns her living through farming. She grows rice crops to sell at the market. Lenida has had problems funding her farm. When she heard of CEVI and learned that it helps farmers like her, she immediately joined to avail of its services. Lenida is now requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She is thankful for the help extended to her and hopes for the loan to help improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Tajikan

texts.en:
Tajikan D. is 52, widowed and has three children. She worked as an economist for a long time and was known as a very responsible and accurate person. In 1993, in order to find an additional means of subsistence for her children, she started her business in sales. With the initial capital of 10,000 KGS she managed to develop her business. She earned a monthly profit of 100,000 KGS from selling women’s clothes at the local market. Her loyal customers were attracted by her attentive attitude and cheerfulness.

But in June 2010, when violent clashes caused by the deposed political regime broke out in the Osh city, Tajikan lost her business. Her shop was robbed and looted.

However, Tajikan isn't giving up. She is ready to resume her lost business and continues to work. For this very reason, Tajikan is applying for a loan of 135,000 KGS, which she needs to restart her business. She plans to purchase more women’s clothing to resell at the local market.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas. These services lead to increased employment and help to meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to buy women's clothing to resell.

Marlene has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

Marlene is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vegetables & spices. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Marlene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Olga

texts.ru:
Ольга Cмоленская родилась в городе Бишкек, Кыргызстан. Ей 56 лет. В 1973 году, окончив среднюю школу, Ольга поступила в училище на курсы бухгалтеров, а после, в 1983 году, она стала студенткой факультета русского языка и литературы Гуманитарного Института. На последнем курсе института Ольга вышла замуж, ее сыновья родились один за другим.  В 1977 году, окончив институт, Ольга была направлена работать в Лицей преподавателем русского языка в село Боролдой. Проработав более 6 лет Ольга, решила не возвращаться в город Бишкек и обустроить свою жизнь в селе. Несмотря на то, что семья Ольги была городскими жителями,  перебравшись в сельскую местность, они понемногу обзавелись хозяйством - купили телочку, затем корову, возделывали небольшую земельную долю, которую сельская администрация выделила для выращивания своих кормов.  2004 год стал для Ольги тяжелым временем – умер ее старший сын, а затем, некоторое время спустя, от сердечного приступа умер ее муж. За небольшое время Ольга перенесла самые большие потери в своей жизни, потеряв родных ей людей. После гибели сына и мужа Ольга долгое время не могла прийти в себя, но нашла в себе силы для преподавания в Лицее, ставшее большим стимулом для дальнейшей жизни.  
В январе 2010 года Ольга  впервые обратилась в компанию «Бай Тушум и Партнеры» и получила свой первый  кредит в размере 30, 000 сом (KGS), который помог ей приобрести скот. В настоящее время у Ольги в хозяйстве содержится две коровы. Сейчас Ольга планирует взять второй кредит в сумме 60, 000 сом (KGS) на дополнительное расширение поголовья скота. 
Ольга верит, что ее воспитанники достигнут высот в жизни и станут одними из самых  выдающихся деятелей. 
ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" предоставляет кредиты по линии Кива для социально-уязвимых слоев населения. ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" является одной из лидирующих Микрофинансовых организаций Кыргызстана. "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" – это надежный финансовый партнер, осуществляющий вклад в развитие экономики Кыргызской Республики путем предоставления доступных микрофинансовых услуг в сельской местности и городах, способствующих созданию рабочих мест и отвечающий интересам своих клиентов и инвесторов.
texts.en:
Olga S. was born in the city of Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. She is 56 years old. In 1973, after graduating from high school, Olga entered accounting school.  Later, in 1983, she started studying Russian Language and Literature at the Institute of the Humanities.  In her senior year, Olga married and her sons were born one after another.  In 1987, after she graduated, Olga was sent to teach Russian in Boroldoy villiage.  After working there for more than six years, Olga decided not to return to Bishkek but to live in the village. In spite of the fact that Olga's family was city dwellers, once they got to the country they built themselves a family farm.  They bought a calf, then a cow, and they cultivated a small plot of land that the rural administration has allocated for growing feed. 

Olga’s hardest time was 2004.  Her eldest son died, and then a bit later, her husband died of a heart attack. In a short time Olga lost two of the closest people in her life.  After her son and husband died, Olga found herself unable to function.  Eventually, her teaching work gave her reason to continue living. 
In January, 2010 Olga applied for her first loan from Bai Tushun and Partners, and received 30,000 som (KGS) which she used to buy cattle. Now Olga’s family farm contains two cows. Olga plans to take out a second loan for 60,000 som (KGS) to further expand her herd.

Olga believes that her students will attain greatness in life and become some of the world’s most outstanding figures.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to  purchase cattle

Asein U. is 63 and married with three children. He has been engaged in livestock breeding since 2001, which is the only mean of subsistence for his family. It will allow him to further broaden his business activities and accumulate money to purchase a flat for his daughter.

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina T. is 56, married and has five children. She has been working as a teacher of the Kyrgyz language and literature at the school of Kyzyl-Ozgorush village for the last 32 years. She is known as a very persistent and responsible person.   Unfortunately, wages of teachers are low and do not cover their household expenses. That’s why, in 1999, Irina started her business breeding cattle. She worked hard and today has a farm with one horse, ten cows and five bulls. In 2009, she took her first loan from Bai Tushum. It was repaid in full and without any delays. Now Irina plans to use this loan of 80.000 KGS to purchase milk cows, which will allow her to increase the number of her cattle. With the revenues, she wants to buy a plot of land to construct a barn for her cattle.

loans.name: Kavule Effort Development Group C

texts.en: Juliet N., age 42, has been engaged in a clothing and shoe sales enterprise for the past 12 years in Mukono Town. This happily-married mother of six says she was inspired by one of her closest friends to set forth in this business. Before that, she mostly performed odd jobs. Hard work and determination have been her pillars as she goes about her business. Her business generates 300,000 UGX per week as profit. With this loan, Juliet says she is going to purchase more bales of clothing and pairs of shoes to resell.

loans.name: Leo

texts.en:
Leo is a 42-year-old married man and father of 2 children. His children are 10 and 7 years old. Leo is a farmer working in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. He cultivates his land for planting rice crops. Leo spends hours on the farm making sure his land free of weeds and pests. He works hard to have a healthy product that he can sell at market.

Leo's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Janeth

Janeth A. is from the village of West Kibawe, Kibawe, Bukidnon. She is 32 years old. Janeth is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Janeth owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling junk foods, candies, ready to wear clothing, sandals & slippers in the local community. Janeth has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Janeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Janeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used towards working capital and to purchase additional inventory. Janeth is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock of sandals & slippers. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Janeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Duishonaly

texts.en:
Duishonaly A. is 62, married and has six grown children. He worked as a teacher at the local school and is known as a responsible and open-hearted person.  Now he is on pension and in order to cover the expenses of his household, he decided to engage in cattle breeding.  Duishonaly started this business with the help of his first loan from Bai Tushum in 2008 and managed to develop a farm with 2 horses, 23 sheep, 12 goats and 3 milk cows. With the revenues, he was able to build a barn at the village outer territory, where he pastures his cattle until the first snow. 

Duishonaly has applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase cattle. It will allow him to increase the number of animals and further broaden his business. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Buumayram

texts.en:
Buumayram M. is 48, widowed and has six children. Her two elder children live on their own and the others live with her and attend school.  As Buumayram is the only breadwinner for her children, she works hard in her livestock-breeding business. Her farm has 2 milk cows and 13 sheep. She also cultivates potatoes and corn. Buumayram has applied for a loan of 60,000 KGS to purchase a milk cow and 10 sheep.  With the revenues, she plans to further increase her business, which will allow her to pay for a good education for her children. 
 
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. To make a living, Luzvimin owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling junk foods, canned goods, beverages, candies, & biscuits in the local community. Luzvimin has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 12000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luzvimin joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Luzvimin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Luzvimin is requesting a new loan of 23000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods & beverages. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Luzvimin from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 61 years old and married with one child.  Lucia works very hard to provide for them.

Lucia runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy more products to sell in her sari-sari store.

Lucia has been in this business for 20 years and sells a variety of items such as soft drinks, candies and other instant foods. 

In the future, Lucia would like to repair and renovate her house to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia, a 50-year-old married woman, has 2 children--aged 23 and 16. She and her husband are both farmers. Lucia does her best to keep their farm productive. She plants rice crops and makes sure they grow healthy. Lucia wants to help improve her family's living conditions.

Lucia's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Ninfa

texts.en:
Ninfa works hard to support her family. Ninfa is married and has a business buying and selling ready to wear clothing in the Philippines.

Ninfa requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock like pants, t-shirts, shorts, etc to sell.

Ninfa has been in this business for four years now.

In the future, Ninfa would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell

Maksat S. is 31, married and has two school-age children.  He has been engaged in breeding animals since 1999 and worked hard to reach success. Today his farm, which has 4 cows, 20 sheep and 2 horses, gives a profit of 4,000 KGS a month.  In order to develop his farm, Maksat has applied for a loan of 60,000 KGS to purchase cattle.  It will allow him to increase his business and renovate his family's house. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic is 50 years old and married with four children. Marivic works very hard to provide for them.

Marivic runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell in her sari-sari store.

Marivic has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as soft drinks, soap, sugar, noodles etc.

In the future, Marivic would like to build and expand her business for the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Suren

texts.en: Suren D. lives in Brnakot village with his wife, two children and parents. He works in the army as a contract serviceman. Suren’s salary is too low to meet the family needs, so he is also engaged in agriculture. Suren wants to renovate his house, but he doesn’t have enough financial means. With the requested loan, he plans to buy seeds, fertilizer and fuel and develop agriculture. With the help of the loan, Suren will increase his income, renovate his house and insure better living conditions for his family.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer and fuel

loans.name: Winena

texts.en:
As a widowed parent of nine children, Winena works hard to support her family.

She has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from frozen foods.  Winena is borrowing 19,500 PHP through NWTF to buy additional vegetables to sell for her business.

Winena has been sustaining her business activities through her past 13 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy additional vegetables to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aisalkyn

texts.en:
Aisalkyn S. is 40, married, and has two daughters.  She is engaged in breeding cattle, and with the help of her husband has managed to maintain her farm successfully, which they started with the initial capital of 3.000 KGS.  They worked hard and managed to earn about $172 in a month from selling milk and meat. With the revenues, they bought a car for their family and paid for education for the children.  

Aisalkyn has applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase cattle. It will allow her to increase her sales of milk products, and in the future will improve her household. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Milagrosa

texts.en:
Milagrosa works hard to support four children. She is married and has a seaweed culture business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 20 years. 

She requested a 19,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy raw materials for her business. In the future, Milagrosa would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her seaweed business.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary K. K. is 36 years old. She is single and has two children, ages 24 and 20. Her business is located at a busy, growing trade center called Kinanie, and she is served by the Kitengela branch. She owns a grocery store in which she sells fruits and vegetables to the local people. She has been in this business for ten years. She says that the business is profitable and that the only major challenge is that there are many people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 80,000 KES to buy more kale, tomatoes, capsicums, and other vegetables to expand her business and to meet the demands of her customers. In the future, she hopes to grow her business and even open a retail shop. She describes herself as a very innovative lady.

loans.use: to buy more kale, tomatoes, capsicums, and other vegetables.

To make a living, Tessie operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling frozen foods like hot dogs and tocino (pork) in the local community. She is also selling and dealing in plastic wares and ready-to-wear clothing from NATASHA & Tupperware. Tessie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 12,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2008, Tessie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional stock of plastic wares, blouses and t-shirts. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Tessie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Nenita is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She is 57 years old and she has two children who are in school. She has a seaweed culture business in the Philippines and has been in this business for twenty years. 

Nenita requested a 17,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy more seedlings of goso (green algae or seaweed) for the expansion of her seaweed culture business.  In the future, she would like to build and expand her business for the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more seedlings of goso.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Rosalinda is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She is 43 years old and has one child who is in school. She has a fishing business in the Philippines and has been in this business for six years. 

Rosalinda requested a 13,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to purchase fishing nets and other equipment for her fishing business.  In the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets and other equipment for fishing.

loans.name: Nazli's Group

texts.en:
Nazli belongs to Faisalabad which is located in Punjab, Pakistan and known for its textile industry. She has been living there in the area of Mariam Abad with her family in a 2-room brick house for the past 10 years. 

Her husband's name is Z. M. and he operates a vegetable shop in the community where he offers a variety of seasonal vegetables to his clients at reasonable prices. In his business, he never compromises on quality and always provides good quality vegetables to his customers and that’s why he has a sizable clientele. 

Nazli is the mother of  a 15-year-old son who is studying in class 10. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. Using the loan, he will buy fresh seasonal vegetables to sell in his shop. This will help him maintain his good name among his customers and earn better profits. 

Nazli is hopeful that after the loan investment, her husband’s business will improve further and earn him better profits. She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application with Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Nazli.

loans.use: To buy fresh seasonal vegetables for vegetable-selling business.

loans.name: Orozobek

texts.en:
Orozobek S. is 55, married, and has four children. He worked as a driver, and in order to find an additional means of subsistence for his family he started his business of cattle breeding in 2006.  With the initial capital of 15,000 KGS, he managed to develop a farm with a monthly profit of about $86.  With the revenues, he was able to pay for a good education for his elder daughters and to buy a car for his family.   

Orozobek has applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase two bull calves and ten sheep. It will allow him to further improve his household and in the future, to expand his business activities by building a bath house for the local population.  

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle and sheep.
