Nilda is a 49-year-old married woman with six children. Her oldest child is 25 years old.

loans.use: to purchase six piglets, feeds and farm fertilizers

loans.name: Zhanyl

texts.en:
Zhanyl B. is 50 years old, married, and has two sons. Her younger son’s family lives with her, and not so long ago she became the grandmother of a beautiful girl. Zhanyl worked at the kindergarten for a long time and was the best friend to her pupils. 

In order to find an additional means of subsistence for her family, she engaged in the cattle breeding business. Starting with the initial capital of 4,000 KGS, she managed to earn about $129 in a month. Today her farm, which consists of two milk cows, a bull calf and five sheep, still needs to be developed. 

For this reason, Zhanyl has applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS for the purchase of one bull calf and fifteen lambs. With the revenues, she plans to reconstruct a barn for her cattle. In future, she dreams of buying a flat in Karabalta town. 


Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is 37 years old and married with two children. She works hard to provide for her family by running a general store in the Philippines. She has been running the store for six years and also earns an income from farming and pig fattening.

She requested a 30,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like sugar, sardines, groceries, etc. in her general store. She has borrowed and paid off 8 loans from NWTF before this loan. 

Elena aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en:
Mr. Batbayar, 33 years old, lives with his wife and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Batbayar’s wife is looking after her baby at the moment. Batbayar works two jobs. He works in a tire repair garage as a mechanic and he transports people around the city in his taxi. He has been running a taxi since 2005. 

Mr. Batbayar's family lives in ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. The ger is now very old and needs to be replaced. The ger has a wooden frame construction and is covered with sheep wool felt. The loan Mr. Batbayar is taking will be used to buy a new ger for his family. A small part of the loan will be used to service his car.

loans.use: To buy a new ger for his family. A portion of the loan will be used to service his car.

loans.name: Kalnisa

texts.en:
Kalnisa N. is 53 years old, widowed, and has four children.  She works as a nurse at the local hospital and is known as an open hearted and responsible person.  In order to find the means to cover all the household expenses of her family, she started her business in cattle breeding and land cultivating.  With the start-up capital of 5,000 KGS, she managed to develop a farm with three milk cows and three calves.  Also she was able to buy one milk cow through selling her harvest of raspberries, apples and pears.  

Now, Kalnisa plans to use this loan of 60,000 KGS to purchase cattle as well as fertilizers to manure her land. With the revenues, she plans further broadening of her business activities.  


Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. Gilda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita T. is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing and fish-selling business in the Philippines. 

Elenita has been in this business for 20 years. Elenita also earns income from raising chickens.

Elenita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. 

She is borrowing PHP 25,000  through NWTF to buy a new engine for her fishing boat.

She dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a new engine for her fishing boat.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph G. W. is a married man. His wife stays at home to take care of the household chores while Joseph goes out everyday to run their charcoal business. They have two children, aged twenty years old and eighteen years old. They hope to give their children a good education to the university level. 

Joseph's business is located at South B estate in Nairobi and he is served by the Kitengela branch. He runs a charcoal business and sells to the local people. He has been in this business for eleven years now. He says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge he has is financial constraints. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of KES 50,000 to add stock of charcoal to grow his business and to meet the demand of his customers. He sees himself becoming the next charcoal supplier in South B. In the future, he hopes to build rental houses. He describes himself as hardworking, honest and punctual.

loans.use: to buy charcoal.

loans.name: Elmira

texts.en:
Elmira A. is 39, married and has two sons, 5 and 3 years old. 

She has been engaged in clothing sales at the central market of Kara-Balta town for the last 11 years. Her start-up capital sum of 10,000 KGS was directed to purchasing a batch of women’s and men’s clothes for retail. She worked hard and today she has a developed business with floating capital of 90,000 KGS. 

With the revenues, she is able to pay for a kindergarten and provide her children with all they need. Elmira has applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS to broaden the assortment of goods she sells. With the revenues she plans to open her own shop and, in the future, to buy a minivan for her family. 
 
Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors. Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population.

loans.use: to broaden the assortment of goods she sells.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna M. is a hardworking entrepreneur who has an RTW (Ready-To-Wear) clothing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 19,500 through NWTF to buy more stock for her business.

Edna has been in this business for three years. Edna earns additional income from farming sugarcane.

Edna has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia F. is from the village of Kiraging, South Cogon, Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old. Letecia is married and has 4 grown children. To make a living, Letecia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, junk foods, shampoo, soap & electronic loads from several networks like GLOBE & SMART in the local community. Her husband provides multi-purpose cab services. Letecia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Letecia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Letecia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used towards working capital and to purchase additional inventory. Letecia is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods & electronic loads. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Letecia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods & electronic loads.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn P. is 45 years old and married. She has five children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Evelyn has been raising pigs for 20 years and also earns additional income from a tricycle (motorcycle with passenger cab) transport business.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream to save money to expand her business.

Evelyn is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy additional pigs, feed and vitamins.

loans.use: To buy additional pigs, feed and vitamins.

loans.name: Belek

texts.en:
Belek A. is a 60-year-old farmer who lives with his family in Cholok-Aryk village. 

As he has been engaged in cattle breeding for the last 30 years and has a wide experience in this activity, he has managed to maintain the farm successfully with a monthly profit of 8.000 KGS. With the revenues, he was able to pay for the education of his children. 

Today he has two horses, three bull calves and two heifers at his farm, which still needs to be developed. For this reason, Belek has applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase one milk cow and fifteen sheep. This will allow him to further broaden his business and in the future, to buy a car. 

 Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors. Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny is 32 years old and married with one child. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell like noddles, groceries, etc. in her general store.

Jenny has borrowed and repaid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

Jenny  aspires to save enough to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To buy additional stock to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen works hard to support two children. She is married and has a fruits and vegetables vending business in the Philippines. 

Carmen requested a 1,800 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy an Envirofit cookstove. 

She is getting the Envirofit cookstove because she wants to make the firewood that she buys last longer--the Envirofit stove needs less fuel to cook food. 

Carmen is aware that by using the Envirofit cookstove, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase an Envirofit cookstove

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en:
Tamara K. is 53, married, and has five children.  She has been engaged in breeding animals and land cultivating since 1995 and has achieved success. Today she is the owner of the farm, which counts three cows, two calves, one horse and seventy sheep. She sells milk and meat products to local customers and earns about 10,000 KGS in a month. All these activities have allowed Tamara pay for a good education of her elder children and give good dowries to her daughters.       

Tamara wants to use this loan of 130,000 KGS to purchase sheep. With the revenue, she plans to build a huge barn for cattle for further development of her business. This will allow her accumulate money for payment for good education of her son. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Sari Ayu Group

texts.en:
Ni Nengah M. is chairperson of the group SA. Ayu. This group consisted of 10 women who have the same job, that is, raising pigs to help support their families. With a loan of Rp.1,000,000 per member, they will buy two pigs of superior breed. Currently they are raising pigs of local breeds.

Ni Nengah M. wll use the loan to buy two pigs of superior breed. She already has a good cage at her home and raises a kind of local pig. She wants to increase business revenue by raising superior breed pigs. She hopes these efforts will grow and be able to finance the needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy two pigs of superior breed.

loans.name: Jerlyn

texts.en:
Jerlyn is 38 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Jerlyn is borrowing PHP 16,000 through NWTF to purchase pigs, feed and vitamins. Jerlyn has been raising pigs for 9 years and also earns additional income from a transportation (tricycle) business.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream:  to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase pigs, feed and vitamins.

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy G. is from the village of Bal-ason, Gingoog City. She is 40 years old. Juvy is married and has three school-aged children. Juvy owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling green and yellow bananas & coconuts in the local community. Juvy has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2010, Juvy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 5000 PHP and was used to purchase additional inventory & for working capital. 

This loan will be her second from HSPFI. Juvy is requesting 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional bananas & coconuts. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI: 

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase bananas & coconuts

loans.name: Lecile

texts.en:
Lecile is 20 years old and single. She works very hard to provide for herself and her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. in her sari-sari store .

Lecile has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap, bread, noodles, soft drinks, rice, etc. In the future Lecile would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn works hard to support her family. Evelyn is married and has a vegetable selling business in the Philippines. 

Evelyn is borrowing 1,800 Philippine pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy an Envirofit cookstove. 

She is getting the envirofit cookstove because she wants to lessen the amount of firewood that she uses when cooking food for her family. 

Evelyn is aware that by using the envirofit cookstove, she is saving money, helping the environment, and reducing health risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase Envirofit cookstove

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Masida

texts.en:
Masida  N. is 49, widowed, and has three children. At the present time, she is the caregiver for her two grandchildren and their best friend. Masida has been engaged in breeding livestock and farming since 2005 and works hard to cover all the expenses of her family.  Starting with the initial capital of 30,000 KGS, she managed to develop a farm with cows, sheep, and goats with monthly earnings in the amount of 8,000 KGS from selling meat and milk products.  

Also, her land with potatoes, corn, tomatoes and onions gives good harvests, which allow adding to her family’s budget about 6,000 KGS in a month. In 2006, Masida took out her first loan from Bai Tushum and Partners to enlarge her herd of livestock. The loan was used as intended and repaid without any delays. During her loan period, she gained a reputation as a responsible, persistent and hard-working person doing her best to provide the family with the essentials. 
 
Now Masida plans to use this loan in the amount of 100,000 KGS to purchase sheep. With the revenue, she wants to improve conditions for good maintenance for her livestock. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora R. is from the village of Minlagas, San Luis, Gingoog City. She is 34 years old. Leonora is married and has three school-age children. Leonora owns and operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables, like eggplants and string beans. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Leonora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers for newly planted crops. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Leonora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for newly planted crops

location.town: Minlagas, San Luis, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita is 55 years old. She is married and has four children. Lolita works very hard to provide for them. She runs a gasoline retail business in the Philippines and requested a 10,000-Philippine-peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase more gasoline to sell. Lolita has been in this business for 26 years. In the future, Lolita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more gasoline to sell

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie is 43 years old. She is married and has one child. Melanie works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a 22,000-Philippine-peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase items like eggs, juice, and groceries to sell in her sari-sari store.

Melanie has borrowed and repaid 20 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 10 years. She also earns an income from electronic recharging. Melanie aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Aitbubu

texts.en:
Bai Tushum and Partners expresses gratitude to all Kiva lenders who helped Aitbubu J. obtain her first Kiva loan, which was used as intended and repaid.

Aitbubu J. is a 63-year-old farmer who lives in the high-mountain Ak-Tala region in Kyrgyzstan. She is married and has six children. Her family has been engaged in cattle breeding for the past 17 years. It is their only means of subsistence. Today Aitbubu has six cows, twelve goats, four horses, and fourteen sheep. To reduce expenses for the livestock's foraging, she pastures her livestock in the mountainous areas with native grasses. Aitbubu is also engaged in cultivating wheat and holy clover, part of which she sells to local customers. With the revenues from these activities, Aitbubu managed to help her daughter to buy a car. Now Aitbubu is applying for a loan of 25,000 Kyrgyzstani som (KGS) to buy bull calves. With the revenues, she plans to broaden her business by means of breeding. 

Bai Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: 50 Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Cầu Lê Thị (3) is a 61 year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Cầu is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 50 Quảng Hưng (18.6.50 Quảng Hưng). 

Cầu is widowed and has five adult children. To making a living, Cầu raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for sale. Cầu has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,000,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) a month from these activities. 

In 2009, Cầu joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Cầu has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will also be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. This loan will be the fourth loan she has taken out from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Cầu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 

1. H. Thị Hương (2) is a 31-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her furniture-making business. 

2. N. Thị Thanh (6) is a 53-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her livestock raising business. 

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: 

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. 

Cầu Lê Thị (three) là 61 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Cầu là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có three các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 50 Quảng Hưng (18.6. 50 Quảng Hưng). 

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán. Cầu thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Cầu kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND. Vào 2009, Cầu đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/anh ấy. Cầu đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND. 

Khoản vay sẽ là fourth khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. 

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 

1. H. Thị Hương (two) là 31 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất. 

2. N. Thị Thanh (six) là 53 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: 

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. 

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch.. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.. "

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

texts.en:
Venancia works hard to support two children. She is married and has a  vegetable-selling business in the Philippines. 

Venancia requested a 3,500 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy a solar lamp. 

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to have backup light in case of emergency. 

Venancia is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase a solar lamp

loans.name: Lecilda

texts.en:
Lecilda A. is from the village of Santiago, Gingoog City. She is 35 years old. Lecilda is married and has five school-age children. Lecilda owns and operates a food stall, selling snacks and other delicacies, like bread, rice cakes, pudding, and cups of coffee and milk, in the local community. Lecilda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2009, Lecilda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lecilda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients for rice cakes. Lecilda is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional bread, flour, milk, and coffee. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Lecilda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 30 years old and single. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Myrna is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. Myrna has been raising pigs for five years and also earns additional income from the selling of hollow blocks.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save more for future needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Merlie

texts.en:
Merlie works as a farmer in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato, Philippines. She grows rice crops to sell. Merlie is a hard-working mother. She wants to help her husband provide for the family. She put up a sari-sari (variety) store to help with their daily needs.  She sells items like canned goods, shampoo and chips.

Merlie's loan will be used to purchase farm fertilizers and other farm supplies.

In the future, Merlie hopes for her children to be successful.

loans.use: to purchase farm fertilizers and other supplies.

loans.name: 81 Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Phượng (150) is a 34-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Phượng is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 81 Quảng Hưng (18.1.81 Quảmg Hưng).

Phượng is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Phượng operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing hotel services to local community members.  Phượng has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 2,100,000 Vietnamese dong a month from these activities.

In 2011, Phượng joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Phượng is requesting for the first loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  The new loan of 4,248,000 VND will be used to invest in expanding the business. Phượng plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  Hằng  (152) is a 33-year-old female who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her food stall.

2.  Nhàn (149) is a 29-year-old female who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to raise livestock.

3. Phúc  (151) is a 51-year-old female who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her food stall.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Phượng (150) là 34 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá.  Phượng là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 81 Quảng Hưng (18.1.81 Quảmg Hưng).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ nói chung cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Phượng thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Phượng kiếm được khoảng 2.100.000 VND.  Vào 2011, Phượng đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Phượng đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4.248.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Hằng  (152) là 33 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


2.  Nhàn (149) là 29 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


3.  Phúc  (151) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to repair the room for renting to students or workers

loans.name: Razelou

texts.en:
Razelou is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a hollow block business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy supplies for her hollow block-making business. Razelou has been in this business for six years. She earns additional income from selling gasoline.

Razelou has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of doing some house improvements in the future.

loans.use: To buy supplies for hollow block-making.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph V. is from the village of Minlagas, San Luis, Gingoog City. He is 36 years old. Joseph is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Joseph owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables like eggplants & squash. Joseph has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 8500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Joseph joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joseph has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Joseph is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers for new crops. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Joseph from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for new crops.

location.town: Minlagas, San Luis, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Corsine

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Corsine works hard to support her family. She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening.  Corsine is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy more fish to sell for her fish vending business.

Corsine has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: 4 Đông Hải Group

texts.en: Toán Lê Thị (263) is a 55-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Toán is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 4 Đông Hải (16.5.4 Đông Hải ). Toán is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Toán raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Toán has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 500,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) a month from these activities. In 2011, Toán joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Toán is requesting for the first time a loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. The new loan of 4.248.000 VND will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Toán plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1. N. Thị Thanh (259) is a 33-year-old female who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to raise livestock. 2. N. Thị Hiền (260) is a 35-year-old female who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to raise livestock. 3. N. Thị Lơn (262) is a 59-year-old female who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to raise livestock. 4. Lê Thị Lưu (264) is a 61-year-old female who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to raise crops. 5. Lê Thị Huyền (261) is a 52-year-old female who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to raise livestock. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Toán Lê Thị (263) là 55 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Toán là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 4 Đông Hải (16.5.4 Đông Hải ). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi heo để bán. Toán thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 15 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Toán kiếm được khoảng 500.000 VND. Vào 2011, Toán đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Toán đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4.248.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. N. Thị Thanh (259) là 33 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. N. Thị Hiền (260) là 35 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 3. N. Thị Lơn (262) là 59 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 4. Lê Thị Lưu (264) là 61 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực. 5. Lê Thị Huyền (261) là 52 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.

loans.name: Ntonwa United And Credit Association Group

texts.en: Assad B. is the leader of Ntonwa United group in Kyenjojo. He is 50 years old and married with 15 children, out of which five are still in school. Assad has a carpentry workshop in the Ntonwa Trading Centre that he has owned for over seven years. He is able to generate 30,000 Ugandan shillings weekly. His customers are mostly home-use customers buying chairs, cupboards and so on that he makes. He is also involved in crop agriculture and cattle-keeping. Assad is hardworking and self-motivated and his dream is to have a financially growing business and a socially stable family. He needs a loan to be able to buy more timber for his workshop.

loans.use: to buy timber for making furniture.

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla is 52 years old and is a married woman with three children. Her oldest child is 34 years old and the youngest is 20. 

Perla is a farmer working in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She grows rice and cassava. Perla rents a stall in the market to sell her harvest. Perla works hard to provide for the needs of her family. She also wants to have savings for future emergencies.

Perla's loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Shirly

texts.en:
Shirly, 40 years old, is a married woman with five children. Her oldest child is 11 years old and the youngest is 4 months.

Shirly is a farmer and so is her husband. They work together to sustain their family. They primarily grow rice crops to sell. Shirly said she joined CEVI because they really need funding for the farm. She is requesting a loan of 16,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

In the future, Shirly hopes for her children to finish college and be successful.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Gandorj

texts.en:
Mr. Gandorj is 39 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His two children go to a local secondary school. Gandorj’s wife, Otgonbayar, used to run a transportation business carrying people using her family minibus. But recently city authorities toughened the requirements for public transport and as a result, she lost the permission to carry people in her minibus. She is a professional chef and currently she is looking for a job in the kitchen. 

Batbayar is man of ambition. Batbayar is building a house, garage, fence and shed to install a heating system. Currently the garage, fence and shed are almost done; he needs to install the big doors to the garage and fence. He is planning to complete the house next year. The loan Gandorj is taking will be used to buy metal doors for the garage and fence.

loans.use: to buy metal doors for the garage and fence.

loans.name: Irshaad's Group

texts.en:
Irshaad is 38 years old and the mother of seven children. All of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. Irshaad takes care of them very well and tries to give them comfort by fulfilling their needs. 

She is married to F. M. who operates a sweetmeat-selling business. His shop is located in the market and he offers good quality and a variety of sweetmeats to his customers. Irshaad also helps him by preparing sweetmeats for his shop. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. Through the loan, her husband will buy required items such as sugar, milk, dried fruits and cooking oil, etc. to prepare a larger quantity of sweetmeat and sell them at a better profit. 

Irshaad is hopeful that an investment will be a productive one for her husband and he will be able to gain maximum profits from it. 

She belongs to Arifwala, a small city which is located in Punjab, Pakistan and known for its dairy industry. Her house contains 3 rooms where she has been living with her family for the past 10 years.

loans.use: To buy required ingredients for her husband's sweetmeat-sales business.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 61 years old, married and has 4 grown children.  She earns a living through farming.  She grows rice and vegetables. 

She rents a stall at the market to sell her harvest.  Teresita works hard to improve her family's living conditions.

Teresita is planning to use her loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.  She hopes for this loan to help improve her business and earnings.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa is 38 years old and is a married woman with 5 children.  Her oldest child is 12 years old.  Three of her children go to school.

Theresa is a farmer working in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato.  She grows rice crops to sell.  She also owns and manages a sari-sari store where she sells items like shampoo, soy sauce and canned goods.  Theresa does all these things to help sustain her family.

She is going to use her loan to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is 45 years old and has three children.  She is married and has one child who is still in school. She is in the agricultural business, farming rice in the Philippines. Rosalina requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

Rosalina has been farming rice for six years now and has borrowed 10 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her activity.

In the future, Rosalina would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
As a married parent of 6 children, Luisa works hard to support her family. She has a fishing business and also earns additional income from frozen foods.  Luisa is borrowing PHP 24,500 through NWTF to buy fishing net and other equipment for her fishing business.

Luisa has been sustaining her business activities through her past 22 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase fishing net and other equipment

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is 37 years old and married, with one child.  Elena works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell.

Elena has borrowed and paid 6 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 10 years and also earns an income from food vending.  Elena aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dashdorj

texts.en:
Mr.Dashdorj is 41 years old and lives with his wife and 2 children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  The two children both attend a local secondary school.  They live in house which they bought four years ago.  

Dashdorj used to be bus driver.  Then he left the job and started running a taxi business and done it for 5 years.  Last year he bought an excavator on a leasing contract from the bank and does different digging jobs on a call basis.  He receives plenty of calls from clients such as digging trenches for cables, pipes, house basements and so on.  The loan he is taking will be used to buy necessary spare parts for his excavator and to carry out some proper maintenance service.

loans.use: To buy necessary spare parts for his excavator and to carry out some proper maintenance service.

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
Ellen works hard to support 4 children.  She is married and has pig raising business in the Philippines.

Ellen requested a 1,500 PHP loan through NWTF to buy an ENVIROFIT COOKSTOVE.

She is getting the envirofit because she wants to reduce the firewood that she uses when cooking.

Ellen is aware that by using the envirofit, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: To buy envirofit cook stove

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita is 56 years old and widowed, with one child.  Carmelita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Carmelita has borrowed and repaid 5 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 2 years and also earns an income from decorations sales.  Carmelita aspires to build and expand her business to provide financial security for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion works hard to support 6 children.  She is a widow and has a local eatery (carinderia) business in the Philippines.

Salvacion requested a 1,500 PHP loan through NWTF to buy an ENVIROFIT COOKSTOVE.

She is getting the envirofit cookstove because she wants to make the firewood that she buys last longer because the Envirofit stove needs less fuel to cook food.

Salvacion is aware that by using the envirofit cookstove, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: To purchase Envirofit Cookstove

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 64-year-old man living in Bint Jbeil. He is the father of 12 children. 

Since 2008, he has sold vegetables in his house and on a carriage. He is a hard worker, a man with good reputation, committed to his work and the quality of products he sells. 

The citizens in Bint Jbeil are his clients. They like the quality he sells. 

Ahmad is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the first time in order to buy fruits and vegetables available in the spring and summer season. 

He is hoping to buy a big and modern pick-up in the future, in addition to providing his family with a secure living. He hopes that all his children are proud of having him as a father.

loans.use: To buy spring and summer seasonal fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Rodelia

texts.en:
Rodelia works hard to support her family. Rodelia is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Rodelia is borrowing PHP 1,500 through NWTF to buy an Envirofit cookstove.

She is getting the Envirofit cookstove because she wants to lessen the amount of firewood that she uses when cooking food for her family.

Rodelia is aware that by using the Envirofit cookstove, she is saving money, helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase an Envirofit  cookstove.

loans.name: Salma's Group

texts.en:
Salma belongs to a small city called Arifwala in Pakistan. Arifwala is known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in a 2-room brick house for the past 10 years. She is married to A. G. and has three children. All of them are very young and studying in a local school. Salma is a housewife, staying at home and doing her household responsibilities.  

Her husband has an animal-selling business. His business grows busier during the Muslim festival of Eid-ul-Azha because people purchase animals to slaughter. At other times he sells animals to butchers. Salma has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who will buy some goats & sheep to further improve his animal-sales business. He has been operating this business for the past 10 years and Salma is confident that her husband will be able to improve the financial condition of his business. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit record and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Salma.

loans.use: To buy goats & sheep for resale.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is a married with two children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Cristina  is 32 years old.

Cristina  has a sari-sari store business in the Philippines. Cristina  requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like sardines, sugar, etc., to sell in her sari-sari store.

Cristina  has been in this business for two years. Cristina would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell in her sari-sari store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aya Efua Theresa

texts.en:
Aya Efua Theresa  E. is divorced and has two children. Educated up to junior high school, Aya Efua runs a provision shop and also sells waakye (rice cooked with beans, usually served with pepper sauce and fish). She has been in this business for five years. 

She now wants to expand her business and is taking a loan from Kiva to purchase more provisions to be able to supply her customers. Aya Efua plans to save up the extra earnings for her two children’s university education.

loans.use: to purchase more provisions for her store.

loans.name: Buloba Development Group

texts.en:
Danata N. is a 50-year-old dairy farmer based in Buloba-Lugazi, which is in central Uganda, East Africa. 

She has been engaged in this business undertaking for six years now. The mother of 10 says it’s a business she enjoys running, given the fact that she is able to make ends meet out of profits from it. She says this business generates an 800,000 UGX profit monthly.

The milk she sells is liked by many of her clients because Danata is known for her cleanliness and hygiene. 

In the future, Danata says she wants to bear a hand in other business ventures such as running her own rental structures. Right now, however, she is fully focused and inclined to bettering her current business fortunes. 

With this loan, Danata says she is going to purchase more cows so that she can get more milk to sell.

loans.use: to purchase more cows.

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy T. is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a sari-sari (variety) store business in the Philippines. 

Juvy has been in this business for two years, and she also earns income from rice retailing.

Juvy has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF

She is borrowing PHP 19,500 through NWTF to buy items to sell like breads, groceries, etc..

She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
As a married mother of six children, Sonia P. works hard to support her family.

She has a pig-fattening business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a motorcycle transport business. 

Sonia is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pig-fattening business.

Sonia has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Roseville

texts.en:
Roseville S. is 51 years old and married. She has six children.

Roseville works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines. She has been running the sari-sari store for 20 years and also earns an income from food vending.

She has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell in her sari-sari store.

Roseville has borrowed and repaid two loans from NWTF before this loan.

Roseville aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Remedios works hard to support her family. She has a fermented fish ("tinabal" making) business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling fruit and vegetables.  Remedios is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her fermented fish business.

Remedios has been sustaining her business activities through her past 34 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her fermented fish making.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Maame Adjoa

texts.en:
Maame Adjoa A. sells soap and ointment at Eguafo near Elmina. 

Educated up to senior high school, she has been in the business for five years.

The income that Maame earns helps supplement her husband’s income. Her husband is a farmer and they have five children. 

She plans to grow her business by producing a larger volume of products for sale. With her loan from Kiva, she’ll be able to purchase more palm fruit and other ingredients to make more soap and ointment. 

Maame intends to reinvest the additional profits back into her business for further growth. 

Maame is pictured next to a pile of palm fruit. Palm oil, which is extracted from the fruit, is a key ingredient for making soap and ointment.

loans.use: to purchase more palm fruit and other ingredients to make more soap and ointment.

loans.name: Farrah

texts.en:
Farrah C. is 23 years old and is a married woman. She has a two-year-old child.

Farrah is a farmer working in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She primarily grows rice crops and then sells her harvest. Farrah works hard to help provide for her family. She is also saving for her child's future.

Farrah will use her loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Zainab's Group

texts.en:
Zainab is very supportive in nature. She always ready to help her husband and family in their time of need. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s agriculture business. 

Her husband owns a small piece of land where he grows different seasonal crops then sells them after the harvest, at a profit.  Through the loan, he will buy fertilizers, seeds and pesticides, etc. that will help him grow better crops and earn more income. 

Zainab is a housewife, spending most of her time doing her household work and staying at home. She has two sons. The elder works in a flour mill while the younger one is studying in class 3. Her husband has been operating his agriculture business for the past 10 years and Zainab is hopeful that an investment will help him make his business more profitable. 

She belongs to Arifwala which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan and known for its dairy industry. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Zainab.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides for agriculture business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase detergents and cleaning machines.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 51-year-old man living in Bint Jbeil and father of two children. He has owned a bakery since 2000, with 10 years of experience. He is a hard worker. He has good reputation for his proficiency at work. His customers are the people living in his town. 

Ahmad is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the first time, in order to buy a silent generator to keep his bakery provided with the necessary electricity when it’s not provided by the government. He hopes to expand the bakery in the future and buy new equipments. He hopes to be the first in his domain and be well known for his good product quality. Ahmad also hopes he can educate his children to be important people in their community.

loans.use: To buy a silent generator necessary to provide his bakery with electricity.

loans.name: Agapita

texts.en:
Agapita is a married woman with three children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Agapita is 35 years old and has two children who are in school.

Agapita has a white abaca processing business (making natural fiber used for spinning)  in the Philippines. Agapita requested a PHP 25,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy raw materials. She has been 20 years in this business. 

 In the future, Agapita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials used to produce fiber.

loans.name: Matilde

texts.en:
Matilde is 46 years old and has seven children.  She is married and has two children who are still in school.

Matilde is in the agricultural business, farming rice in the Philippines. Matilde requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to pay for the rice grains and the laborers for her rice mill. She has been farming rice for 4 years now and has borrowed seven times in the past from NWTF to sustain her activity.

In the future, Matilde would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To pay for the rice grain and the laborers for her rice mill.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca R., 62, is a married woman from Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She has two children aged 34 and 27.

Francisca has been in the business of raising hogs for 12 years. Each month, Francisca earns 3,500 PHP by doing the hog-raising business. Francisca works hard to improve her income. 

In the future, Francisca hopes for her business to be stable.

She plans to use her loan to purchase piglets and feeds.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and feed.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa A. sells palm oil, palm kernel oil and fresh fish at Eguafo near Elmina. Elmina is a fishing community in Cape Coast. 

She has been in this trade for five years. Married to a farmer, she has four children. Her income contributes to their children’s school fees and the household utility bills.
 
Adjoa wishes to grow her fish business, and her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save up for a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fish to sell.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. O. is 37 years old and single. She runs a salon to earn a living. She also sells second-hand clothes for extra income.  

Since she became a member of Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to save her money. This has helped her to manage her business finances.  

She has applied for a loan of 20,000 KES with her shares in Faulu Kenya. She plans to use the money to buy a hair dryer. She aspires to open a hair dressing college in the future.

loans.use: to buy a hair dryer.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Wobulezi in the Luweero region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Lilian has a business selling charcoal, which she has had for three years.  She also has a second business  elling local beer.  

To help expand her business, Lilian has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more charcoal for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Lilian hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Lilian hopes to expand her business. 

 Lilian is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by further improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Duncan

texts.en:
Duncan K. M. is 35 years old and single. To earn a living, he offers photocopying and printing services.  

His determination and hard work has helped him to sustain his business for eight years. He has also been trained on business record keeping and savings by Faulu Kenya. 

He hopes to move to a more spacious business premise and open another outlet in the future. He needs 75,000 KES to buy printing paper,ink and cartridges.

loans.use: To buy printing paper, ink and cartridges.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 43-year-old man living in Bint Jbeil. He has five kids. Working as a hardware dealer, Ali has 10 years of experience. He has good reputation for his commitment to his work. 

Ali is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the fourth time, in order to buy new products to increase his income. His previous loans had a good impact on his family’s social situation.  He is intent on buying a big, modern pick-up in the future, that can fit a larger number of products to sell.

loans.use: To buy new products to increase his income.

loans.name: Lkham

texts.en:
Mrs.Lkham N., a 58-year-old widow, lives in her children's neighborhood in a small ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. Her children live with their spouses and children in separate houses on one plot of land. Since 1998 Lkham has run a furniture-making business first established by her husband. Assisted by some of her children, she sells her products at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in the city.

Having received and repaid a Kiva loan last year, Lkham is now requesting a new one to purchase wood materials to construct new types of furniture including children’s bunk beds and tables and chairs for café and bars, all currently in high demand.

loans.use: to buy more wooden materials to produce furniture.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe DANAYA constitué de cinq femmes : 4 veuves et 1 mariée, ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 2 enfants et vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à MEDINE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur septième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et tous les prêts passés ont été remboursés sans aucune difficulté. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de draps de lit, de pagnes et des fruits et légumes tels les oranges avec ROKIA D.. 
ROKIA D.  compte acheter avec son  prêt 50 chargements de charrette en orange. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de MEDINE .
Les oranges sont revendus au  marché de HAMDALLAYE et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 60.000FCFA, qui sera utilisé  pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The DANAYA group has five women members : 4 widows and 1 married woman whose average age is 40. They have two children and mostly live in polygamous families in Medine, a neighborhood in the city of Sikasso which is the third administrative region of Mali.

They are on their seventh round of borrowing with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their clients. All their previous loans have been repaid without any problems. The group of women is in the business of selling bed sheets, cloth skirts, fruits and vegetables, for example oranges.

With the loan, one of the members, ROKIA D. plans to purchase 50 cart loads of oranges.
She will purchase her supplies at the market in Medine. The oranges are then sold at the HAMDALLAYE market and to families with men and women as clients who pay in cash.

She plans to make an average monthly profit of 60,000 cfa francs which will be used to pay for daily family expenses. She hopes to increase her turnover so she can better serve her clients.

loans.use: to purchase oranges

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 33 years old. She has four children who are between the ages of 7 and 11. Her husband is an electrician. Josephine owns a shop in which she sells several items, such as candles, matches, sugar, and drinks like tea and fresh milk. With this business, she has bought her own family house. She is requesting a loan to reinvest in her business. She plans to reinvest in her business with the profits she hopes to make.

loans.use: to buy more items to put in her shop, such as candles, matches, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Jiguitougou Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe JIGUITOUGOU, 3 mariées  et 2 célibataires ont une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans, et ont en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans les  familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur troisième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés ont été remboursé dans de bonne condition. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de charbon de bois avec NANA D.. 
NANA D.  compte acheter avec son  prêt 50 sacs de charbon de bois et s’approvisionne dans les villages voisins . Le charbon est revendu  en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 90.000FCFA  qui sera utilisée  pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The JIGUITOUGOU group has five women members, three are married and two are single, their average age is 30 and have on average 3 children each. They live mostly in monogamous families in SANOUBOUGOU, a neighborhood in the city of Sikasso, in the third administrative region of Mali.

They are in their third-round of borrowing with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy their client's needs. Their past loans were all properly repaid. This group of women is in the business of selling charcoal.

With the loan, NANA D. plans to purchase 50 bags of charcoal and will purchase the supplies in the neighboring village. The charcoal is then resold to families in the neighborhood to a clientele of both men and women for cash.

She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 90,000 cfa francs which will be used to pay for daily family expenses.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal

loans.name: Zinaida's Group

texts.en:
Zinaida D. is the leader of this group. She is 59 and unfortunately, she is a widow. She has raised five sons and a daughter. The youngest son studies at school and the other children are married and live separately with their families. 

In order to earn a livelihood, Zainaida works as a cook in a trade center “Ak Dan”.  In 2007, she saved 15,000 soms and started a cattle breeding activity.  Selling cattle after fattening, she earns an additional 3000 soms per month. This profit made it possible for her to purchase furniture for her home and improve her living conditions. With money received from the loan, Zinaida will purchase cattle in order to resell it at a higher price after fattening. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Kelenya Group

texts.fr:
Les neufs membres du groupe KELENYA sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans, et en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur huitième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés ont été correctement remboursés. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de vêtement pour enfants, de draps de lit, de pagnes et de pois sucré avec RAMATA T.. 
RAMATA T.  compte acheter avec son  prêt  500 Kg de pois sucré  au grand marché central de la ville de Sikasso. Le pois sucré est  revendu à la gare routière, au marché de SANOUBOUGOU I et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 110.000FCFA  qui sera utilisée rembourser le prêt et  pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en: The nine members of the group KELENYA are all married, and they average 45 years of age and three children each. The women live for the most part in polygamous families in SANOUBOUGOU I, a district in Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are on their eighth collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers. The past loans have been correctly repaid. This group of women does commerce in children's clothing, bed sheets, pagnes (colorful West African cloth), and sweet peas, as in the case of Ms. RAMATA T.. RAMATA T. intends to use her loan to buy 500 kg of sweet peas at the main central market of Sikasso. The peas are resold for cash at the bus station, at the market of SANOUBOUGOU I, and at the house. The customer base is composed of women and men. She envisions making an average monthly profit 110,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan and for day-to-day family expenses.

loans.use: to buy sweet peas

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Wobulezi in the Luweero region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Jessica has a little food stand, which she has had for two years.         

To help expand her business, Jessica has requested a loan of 1,300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more food for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jessica hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself.  In the future, Jessica hopes to own a beauty salon.

loans.use: to purchase more food for resale.

loans.name: Burastan

texts.en:
Burastan M. is from the village of Haykavan in the Shirak region of Armenia. Haykavan has abundant nature, especially for farming.  

Burastan has been engaged as a private entrepreneur for over 35 years. She is married with four children: three daughters (32, 34 and 36 years old) and a 27-year-old son. 

She is looking for a loan to purchase potato seeds and fertilizer. She will seed one hectare of her irrigated land with potato seeds and expects her income this year to increase by 20 percent. She is impressed by the services of microfinance and wants to continue growing her small business.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Soro Yiriwa Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe SORO YIRIWA sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 27 ans, et ont en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à MEDINE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur septième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés ont été remboursés dans de bonne condition. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de draps de lit,   de céréales, d’habits et de chaussures avec MARIAM S.. 
MARIAM S. compte acheter avec son  prêt 100 paires de chaussures. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de MEDINE.
Les chaussures  sont revendues au  marché de MEDINE et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 90.000FCFA utilisée  essentiellement pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille. Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The four members of the group SORO YIRIWA are all married, and they average 27 years of age and three children each.
