The women live for the most part in polygamous families in MEDINE, a district in Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are on their seventh collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers. The past loans have been repaid in the right manner. This group of women does commerce in bed sheets, grains, clothing, and shoes, as in the case of Ms. MARIAM S.. 
 
MARIAM S. intends to use her loan to buy 100 pairs of shoes. She gets her supplies at the main market of MEDINE. The shoes are resold for cash to a customer base composed of women and men at the MEDINE market and at the house. 

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 90,000 francs CFA that will essentially be used for day-to-day family expenses. Her ambition is to increase her turnover to satisfy her customers further.

loans.use: to buy shoes

loans.name: Bikuto Work Hard Group, Kihihi

texts.en: T. Godfrey is the leader of Bikuto Work Hard Group, Kihihi. He is 36 years old. He is married and has five children above the age of 1, with four already in school. Godfrey sells clothes and clothing materials from Butogota by the side of the road, out of his home. At times, he also goes to the daily markets. He has been in business for over seven years, and he is able to generate 250,000 monthly. He is also involved in farming and selling farm produce, and he has a boda-boda that he hires out for a daily fee. He is very hardworking, and this is why he is able to run all his businesses. His dream is to expand his business and educate his children to the highest level. Godfrey needs a loan to be able to buy more clothes for resale.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Barbra

texts.en:
Barbra N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  Barbra has a business selling clothes, which she has had for 2 years.  She also has a second business selling shoes  

To help expand her business, Barbra has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clothes and shoes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Barbra hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes pay school fees for her children.  In the future, Barbra hopes to own a small retail shop.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Kalicha's Group

texts.en:
Kalicha A. is the leader of this group. She is 48 and married to a farmer. She has a daughter and two sons. The daughter works in Bishkek in a sewing workshop, the first son works as a plumber in Russia, and the second son is a builder. 

Kalicha is engaged in bee keeping. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase more bee hives in order to expand her business. In the future, she wants to develop her business to be able to provide some financial support to her children.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase bee hives

loans.name: Haykush

texts.en: Haykush S. lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Gtashen.  She is married with three children. Her two daughters are 20 and 24 years old and her son is 23 years old.  Haykush didn’t have enough savings to purchase seed for the current growing season.  She turned to a microfinance loan for the necessary investment.  With a loan,she will purchase wheat and barley seeds and some animal feed.  This investment should provide her family with an additional 20% income.  Haykush has been farming her land for over 15 years.  She hopes to continue expanding her business and someday pass it on to her children.

loans.use: to buy wheat seeds, barley seeds and animal feed

loans.name: Mumtaz's Group

texts.en:
Mumtaz’s husband is a butcher by profession. He sells good quality meat and good in weight to his customers and that’s why he has a good number of people who come to him to buy meat. 

Mumtaz is a housewife, staying at home and doing her household responsibilities. In her spare time, she also sews clothes to share the financial burden with her husband.  Her earning allows her to pay the utilities. She has given birth to five children but no one is able to attend school due to financial constraints. 

Mumtaz has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to improve his business by purchasing chickens in larger quantity. This will help him fill larger orders on time and earn good income.  He has been operating this business for the past 15 years and Mumtaz is confident that an investment will help  him improve his business further and her family will be able to live a better financial life in a result. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has  paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. 

She belongs to a small city called Arifwala which is located in Punjab, Pakistan and is known for its dairy industry. Her house contains 3 rooms where she has been living with her family for the past 26 years. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Mumtaz.

loans.use: To buy chickens to sell for meat.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has one child.  Her child is not currently in school.  Betty has furniture business that makes beds, which she has had for four years.         

To help expand her business, Betty has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more timber for making beds for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Betty hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Betty hopes to expand her business.    

Betty is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by being able to learn how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase more timber for making beds for resale.

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed belongs to the Fazal colony which is a small housing colony located in a small city called Arifwala. Arifwala is located in Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. 

She married M. A. and has four children. Two of them are studying and the others stay at home. Khursheed herself sews clothes for her neighborhood clients to bear the financial burden with her husband. She operates her business from her home. 

Her husband is a fruit vendor. He put fruit on his cart and visits different streets of the city to sell the fruit. Khursheed has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to buy a new cart because his current cart has become rough and needs replacement.  On the new cart, he will be able to put more fruit which will enable him to operate his business better. 

Khursheed is hopeful that this investment will be a productive one for her husband and will help him make his business more profitable.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Khursheed.

loans.use: To buy a new cart for fruit-selling business.

loans.name: Araksi

texts.en: Araksi T. is from the village of Kaps in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is married with three children: a 24-year-old daughter and two sons (20 and 21 years old).  Araksi has graduated with a veterinary degree.  With her training, she decided to become a private entrepreneur.  Araksi has been raising livestock for the past three years.  The extra money she earns will be saved to pay for her children’s university education.  Araksi is looking for a loan to purchase livestock, wheat seeds and barley seeds.  This investment should increase the family income by 20 %.  She also plans to help her relatives with the produce on the family farm.

loans.use: to purchase livestock, wheat seeds and barley seeds

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en:
Damira T. is the treasurer of this group. She is 48 and married to a postman. Together with her husband, she is bringing up a son and three daughters. The son is a farmer, the first daughter is a nurse, and the other daughters study at school. 

In order to add to the family budget, Damira sells grocery products. At the same time, the family breeds cattle. They have been doing it since 1996, when the collective farms broke up. With money received from the loan, Damira wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the near future she wants to start repairing the house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Bujinlham

texts.en:
Bujinlham is 52 years old. She lives with her husband and daughter, age 18, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, in the outer ger districts of the city. 

Bujinlham offers coping, scanning, and printing services at a rented space. She works there with her husband, who works as a trained English and Russian translator.  

Bujinlham began her service five years ago. Now their daily income amounts to approximately 55,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT). Bujinlham wants to buy new equipment and devices for her computer-service business to improve effectiveness and efficiency. She is requesting a loan of 1,200,000 MNT to buy a new scanner and laser printer to increase her work output.

loans.use: to purchase a new scanner and laser printer

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth N. lives in the Nakulabye neighbourhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has five children, all of whom attend school.  She also takes care of additional family members.  Ruth has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days a week. Ruth sells her products at the market by means of wholesale.   She is requesting a loan for 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy to buy more bags of charcoal.   The main business challenges for Ruth include transportation and thieves.  Her goal for her business is to own a delivery van.   Ruth lives in a home, which she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, medication, and school fees.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Lukia

texts.en:
Lukia is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nasana in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has four children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Lukia has a business selling clothes, which she has had for three years.         

To help expand her business, Lukia has requested a loan of 350,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clothes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Lukia hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Faridah

texts.en:
Faridah N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nassana in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Faridah has a business of selling clothes, which she has had for two years.  She also has a second business selling shoes.  

To help expand her business, Faridah has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clothes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Faridah hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Faridah hopes to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Siranush

texts.en: Siranush T. lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Kaps.  She is married and the proud mother of two children: a 15-year-old daughter and a 19-year-old son.  She considers herself a hard working honest person and for the past 18 years, she has been a farmer.  She has a high school education and dreams for both of her children to graduate from the university.  Her daughter will graduate high school in two years and her son will finish his army service next year.  Siranush is looking for a loan to purchase livestock and wheat seeds.  According to her plan, this investment will increase the family income by 15%.  She is pleased with microfinance services, especially because the monthly repayments are organized to be made in her village.  With many friends and relatives nearby and the fresh air, Siranush enjoys living in Kaps.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and wheat seeds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase motorcycle spare parts and braids for the hair for resale.

loans.name: Tsagaantsooj

texts.en: Mrs. Tsagaantsooj is 57 years old. She lives with her husband and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her son Jamyan is 34. He works for a private company. Her husband, Tumur, is 58. He receives a disability allowance and stays at home. Mrs. Tsagaantsooj works at a cashmere factory as a cleaner. She has three more children who live separately with their families. Last year, Mrs. Tsagaantsooj started building a family house. It is 70 percent complete. The house was built with wooden beams. Some of the walls are covered with basalt wool for insulation purposes. Now she needs to buy more building materials to finish the building work by putting insulation under the floor, on the walls, and under the roof. The Mongolian winter is one of the harshest in the world, reaching minus 45 degrees at night. Therefore, houses need to be well insulated. A well-insulated house burns less charcoal, emitting less poisonous smoke into the air. The loan will be used to buy basalt wool, metal sheets, cement, bricks, and other necessary materials to insulate the house well and complete the housing project.

loans.use: to buy basalt wool, metal sheets, cement, bricks, and other necessary materials to insulate the house well and complete the housing project

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Jesca N. lives in the Nabulagala neighbourhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. Jesca has a business of selling second hand clothes. She has been in this business for one year, and she works seven days out of every week. Jesca sells her products in a shop, by means of wholesale. 

Jesca has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy to buy more bales of second hand-clothes. The main business challenges for Jesca include defaulters, transportation, and the ever-increasing prices of used clothes. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a wholesale shop and also to build rental rooms. 

Jesca lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but not piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, medication, and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Allen

texts.en:
Allen N. lives in the Kanyanya neighbourhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (including a grandson). Allen has a retail shop. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. 

Allen has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and jerycans of cooking oil. The main business challenges for Allen include intermittent electricity, transportation, and the ever-increasing prices of commodities. Her goals are to own a wholesale shop and to build rental rooms. 

Allen lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, medication, and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, and jerrycans of cooking oil

loans.name: Christophe

texts.en: Christophe is 30 years old and single. He sells fish and cooking oil. His business has enabled him to build his own house where he lives. Christophe is requesting a loan to buy more fish and cooking oil for his store. He hopes to reinvest the profit from his loan into his business.

loans.use: to buy fish and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Imad

texts.en:
Imad is a 38-year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil. He is the father of 3 children. 

Imad is the owner of  a clothing store, where he sells clothes for men and women.  He opened his own business in March 2010.  He has a good reputation for his special customer service and good quality of the products. Most of  his clients live in Bint Jbeil.  Imad is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the first time, in order to buy more items for the Spring/Summer collection. He hopes to expand his shop in the future, to provide his kids the best education and his small family a healthy and secure living.

loans.use: To buy new spring/summer items

loans.name: Jeanned’Arc

texts.en:
Jeanne D’arc is a 39-year-old widow with two children who are seven and 12 years old. Both of her children are in school. Jeanne sells second-hand clothing for children and adults. Her business has enabled her pay her children’s school and medical fees. 

Jeanne is requesting a loan to buy more clothes to sell to increase her profits.

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothing to sell

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is 41 years old and married with three children between the ages of one and 15 years old. Justine and her husband sell sweet bananas wholesale. This business has enabled her to feed her family and meet her family’s needs. 

Justine is requesting a loan to purchase more bananas and increase her profits. In the future, she would like to save enough to open up her own shop.

loans.use: to buy bananas to sell

loans.name: Jerlito

texts.en:
Jerlito is a single farmer from the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Jerlito spends hours tilling his land and preparing it for planting rice crops. When not busy farming, Jerlito drives his tricycle to transport people around his community. He works hard to save money and help his family.

Jerlito is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizer and repair his tricycle. In the future, Jerlito hopes that his business ventures prosper.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and repair his tricycle

loans.name: Bawissida Group

texts.fr:
Mme Rasmata est la présidente du groupe BAWISSIDA. Elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants. Le plus âgé a 17 ans et le moins âgé a 04 ans. Quatre(04) de ses enfants vont àl’école et elle prend en charge 08 personnes (ses enfants et ses frères).

Mme Rasmata vend des légumes et de la patte d’arachide depuis 10 ans. Elle s’approvisionne à la cité AN 2 en ville. Ses clients sont ses voisins du quartier.

Mme veut s’acheter 10 plats (youriba) d’arachide et des légumes.

Elle veut économiser pour aider son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille. Elle ambitionne s’acheter un hangar propre à elle-même pour le stockage de l’arachide en sac et aussi s’acheter une parcelle et une moto.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rasmata is the president of the BAWISSIDA group. She is married and the mother of five children. The oldest is 17 and the youngest four years of age. Four of her children go to school and she supports eight persons in all (her children and her brothers). 

Mrs. Rasmata has been selling vegetables and peanut butter for 10 years. She buys her supplies in the AN 2 housing development in the city. Her customers are neighbors from her area. 

She wants to buy 10 trays ("youriba") of peanuts and of vegetables.

She wishes to put aside some savings so that she can help her husband pay family expenses. Her ambition is to buy her own shed where she can store sacks of peanuts, and also buy a plot of land and a motorcycle.

loans.use: to buy 10 trays ("youriba") of peanuts and of vegetables.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay school fees for next term and buy land for agriculture

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy wood for making furniture

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy charcoal, beans, sugar, and maize flour for her shop.

loans.name: Nver

texts.en:
Nver Tonyan lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Nor Kyank (which means New Life in English).  Nver is married, with a sixteen year old daughter.  He is making plans and saving money for his daughter to attend university. 

Nver has a high school education and has been a private entrepreneur for the past seven years. In order to expand his business, he is looking for a loan to purchase flower seeds and fertilizer. According to Nver’s business plan, this investment will increase his net income by twenty percent.  He is pleased with the convenient services of microfinance.  Nver was born in “New Life” and enjoys his rural life surrounded by close friends and relatives.

loans.use: to purchase flower seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie is a farmer working in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. He grows rice and vegetables to sell. Jessie also owns and manages an ice-cream business. Jessie works hard to provide for his family. He wants their living conditions to improve.

Jessie's loan will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizer. He hopes for his farming business to be stable.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Twunguranibitekerezo Group

texts.fr: Emmanuel N. est agriculteur de riz dans le secteur du Ruhuha, membre du group Twunguranibitekerezo et client d’ACB depuis 2010.  Il a 41 ans, il est marie, et il a 6 enfants entre 4 ans et 17 ans.  Quatre de ses enfants vont à l’école.  Emmanuel est ne a Ruhuha, au Rwanda, et il a une éducation d’école primaire.  Ce crédit et son deuxième cycle avec ACB, et il a une bonne histoire d remboursement.  Il va utiliser son prêt pour acheter des fertilisants, et de la main d’œuvre.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’avoir une caisse mutuelle de 5000FRW entre les membres du groupe, avoir une réunion entre les membres du groupe chaque mois, avoir une épargne, et l’augmentation d’étendu de son activité.  Il voudrait améliorer la culture de riz, et donner à chaque membre du groupe une vache dans 5 ans.  Pour sa famille, il voudrait éduquer ses enfants, et les autres membres de sa famille.
texts.en:
Emmanuel N. is a rice farmer in the Ruhuha sector.  He has been a member of the group Twunguranibitekerezo and a client of ACB since 2010. He is 41 years old and married, and he has six children, aged 4 to 17. Four of his children are going to school. Emmanuel was born in Ruhuha, in Rwanda, and he has a primary school education. This loan cycle is his second one with ACB, and he has a good repayment record. 

Emmanuel is going to use his loan to buy fertilizers and to pay for labor. His strategy for business growth is to have a mutual account of 5,000 FRW among the group members; to have monthly meetings of the group members; to have a savings account; and to expand his business. He would like to improve his rice crops and to provide each group member a cow in five years. For his family, he would like to educate his children, as well as the other members of his family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and to pay for labor

loans.name: Speciose

texts.en:
Speciose is 38 years old and a mother to three children who are between the ages of four and eleven. Her husband is a driver. Speciose has been selling vegetables such as cabbages, onions, carrots, etc. for the past two years. 

This business has enabled her make some savings and feed her family as well. She is requesting a loan to buy more vegetables and make more profits.

loans.use: to buy vegetables.

loans.name: Bazira Community Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty-nine-year-old Faridah N. has been subsisting on a food sales business in the heart of Mpigi Food market for the past 3 years. What has been playing in her favor is the fact that she is a farmer. She sells mostly bananas, cassava, maize and cabbage. The happily married mother of 4 has built a track record of hard work and determination over the few years she has been in business. Coupled with her tenacity, civility and good human relationship skills, Faridah anticipates a bright future in her business. 

Faridah has borrowed a loan before and she has built a pedigree of paying back her loans on time. Faridah says she began this business after the completion of school. She also ekes out additional profits from a small fish sales business. Weekly, her food sales trade generates her profits to the tune of 150,000 UGX and she says with this loan, she is going to purchase more foods like rice, potatoes and beans to resell.

loans.use: purchase food such as rice, potatoes and beans to resell

loans.name: Rabih

texts.en:
Rabih is a 36-year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil with his wife and four kids. Since 1990, he has owned farm tractors that he rents to farmers to prepare their lands for each new planting season. 

Rabih  has 26 years of experience. He was too young when he started working, but he was expected to work early because his parents' financial situation was too hard to manage their living without his contribution. Rabih is a man with good reputation, especially in his proficiency at work. 

Rabih is requesting a loan from Al Mjamoua in order to buy a six-wheel, which he believes will increase his income through being able to transport materials and products from one place to another. Rabih has been an Al Majmoua borrower since 2009, and his previous loans had a big effect on his ability to grow his business. 

He would like to expand his business more in the future, and works hard to give his kids the best childhood ever, the one he couldn’t have.

loans.use: to buy a six-wheel vehicle

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca  N. lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has 7 children, all of whom are in school. Rebecca has a business of selling sugar cane. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Rebecca sells her products at the market by means of wholesale/retail. 

Rebecca has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy to buy more bundles of sugar cane. The main business challenges for Rebecca include defaulters, transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van to ease transport. Rebecca lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, medication and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bundles of sugar cane

loans.name: Milly

texts.en:
Milly N. lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 2 children, both of whom are in school. Milly owns a pub. She has been in this business for 4 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. 

Milly has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy to buy more crates of beer and jerry cans of local gin. The main business challenges for Milly include defaulters and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully-stocked bar. 

Milly lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, medication and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer and jerry cans of local gin

loans.name: Cissy

texts.en:
Cissy N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has one child.  Her child is not currently in school.  Cissy has been selling charcoal for one year.  She also has a second business selling fruits and vegetables.  

To help expand her businesses, Cissy has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more charcoal, fruits and vegetables for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Cissy hopes to generate greater profits and pay for her house rent and food.  In the future, Cissy hopes to expand her business. Cissy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal, fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet N. lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has six children, all of whom are in school. Annet also takes care of additional family members. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees. Annet lives in a rented home with electricity and access to running water. She has been in the business of selling wheat flour for less than a year. For six days out of every week, Annet sells her product wholesale from home. 

Annet is requesting a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy to buy more cartons of wheat flour. Her main business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Annet’s goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van. In this photo, she is in the middle wearing a red shirt.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour to sell

loans.name: Abakundisuka Group

texts.fr: Albert S. est agriculteur du riz dans le secteur du Ruhuha, membre du groupe Abakundisuka, et client d’ACB depuis 2009.  Il a 31 ans, il est marie, et il a 3 enfants entre 2 ans et 8 ans.  Un de ses enfants va à l’école.  Il est ne a Bugesera, au Rwanda, et il a une éducation d’école primaire.  Ce crédit est son troisième cycle avec ACB, et il a une très bonne histoire de remboursement.  Il va utiliser son prêt pour l’achat des fertilisants, et le paiement de main d’œuvre.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est l’unité des membres (vivre dans une même agglomération), lutter contre la pauvreté en travaillant sans chercher le repos, et la valorisation de la culture de riz dans sa région.  Il voudrait avoir les machines pour lui aider avec son activité, et avoir une vache au moins pour chaque membre du groupe.  Pour sa famille et lui-même, il voudrait avoir une vache pour donner le lait aux membres de la famille, scolariser ses enfants, et nourrir la famille convenablement.
texts.en:
Albert S. is a rice cultivator in Ruhuha sector. He's a member of Abakundisuka group, and a customer of Kiva's partner, ACB, since 2009. He's 31 years old, married, and the father of three children, age 2 to 8. One of them attend school. He was born in Bugesera, Rwanda, and attended school up to elementary level.

He's seeking his third loan from ACB, and his repayment history is very good. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and pay for labor. His strategy to grow the group's business is uniting its member and living in the same agglomeration, fighting poverty by working restlessly, and valorizing rice cultivation in his region. 

He would like to have machines to help him with his activity, and a least one cow for each member of the group. For himself and his family, he would like to have a cow to provide milk for the family, send his children to school, and feed his family decently.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pay for labor

loans.name: Zuhro

texts.ru: Азизова Зухро проживает в районе Шахринав. Возраст, 42 года. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Её муж работает бухгалтером в колхозе. Сама она занимается торговлей на рынке. Она продает детскую одежду и обувь. Этим видом деятельности занимается 8 лет. Кредит берет для покупки детской и женской летней обуви, то есть для приобретения сезонного товара.
texts.en: Zuhro A. lives in Shahrinav. She is 42 years old, married, and has four children. Her husband works as a bookkeeper on a collective farm. She works trading in the market. She sells children's clothes and footwear. She has been doing this work for eight years.  She is taking out a loan to buy seasonal goods such as women’s and children’s summer footwear.

loans.use: to buy women's and children's summer footwear

loans.name: Sumaya

texts.en:
Sumaya N. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has three children.  All of her children are currently in school. Sumaya has had a tailoring business for over 10 years.  She also has a second business of a beauty salon.  

To help expand her business, Sumaya has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more materials for making clothes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Sumaya hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her sister.  In the future, Sumaya hopes to expand her business. Sumaya is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by being able to provide basic needs for herself.

loans.use: to purchase more materials to make clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a 36-year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil with his wife and two kids. Ibrahim has been a wholesale food supplier since 2006. He is a hard worker with a good reputation for his commitment and proficiency at work. Most of his clients are from Bint Jbeil. 

Ibrahim is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the first time, in order to buy cigarettes and tobacco. He introduces new products gradually to his customers in order to assure his products are all sold out. Ibrahim would like to buy a big and modern pickup truck in the future to transport the products sold to customers as an additional service.

loans.use: to buy cigarettes and tobacco

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has one child.  Her child is not currently in school.  Florence has had a small retail shop for three years.         

To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more essential commodities like soap for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Florence hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Florence hopes to build rental houses. Florence is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by being hardworking and learning more on how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase more essential commodities like soap for resale.

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en:
Gorret N. lives in the Namungoona neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. Gorret lives in a home that she owns and she has electricity but no running water. Her major monthly expenses include paying school fees. For the past seven years, Gorret has run a tailoring business. She works six days out of every week selling her products in a retail shop. 

Gorret is requesting loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy bitenge (African attire) and material. Gorret also generates additional income through farming and her main business challenge is seasonality. Gorret's goals and aspirations are to be able to pay school fees for her children and improve her house.

loans.use: to buy bitenge (African attire) and material

loans.name: Fatumah

texts.en:
Fatumah N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Fatumah has had a business selling clothes for two years.         

To help expand her business, Fatumah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clothes for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Fatumah hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Fatumah hopes to own a big boutique.  Fatumah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her become self employed.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet N. lives in the Bwaise neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has three children, all of whom are in school. Annet lives in a rented home without access to electricity or running water. Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees. For the past ten years, Annet has run a food stall. She works six days out of every week selling products wholesale from her home.

Annet is requesting a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy to buy more bags of cassava and sweet potatoes. Her main business challenges include transportation and seasonality. Annet’s goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van.

loans.use: to buy sweet potatoes and cassava to sell

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica M. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has no children.  Jessica has had a small retail shop for one year.         

To help expand her business, Jessica has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase a fridge and pay electricity bills.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jessica hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Jessica hopes to own a wholesale shop. 

Jessica is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by increasing the capital in her business.

loans.use: to purchase a fridge and pay electricity bills.

loans.name: Hussain

texts.en:
Hussain is a 26-year-old married man living with his wife in Chtoura. He works in construction and has specialized in painting homes and shops. He is a hard worker. 

He started his own business in 2002, with nine years of experience. His clients are friends and his village’s citizens. He has a good reputation for the proficiency and quality of his work. 

Hussein is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the first time, in order to buy iron pillars and an air compressor necessary to improve his business. Hussain wants to improve his business more and more in the future and to support the small family he dreamed about all his life.

loans.use: to buy iron pillars and air compressor necessary for his business

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka, in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Florence has a poultry firm, which she has had for less than one year. To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more poultry feed and chickens for resale. With the help of this loan from BRAC, Florence hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Florence hopes to build a house.

Florence is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by enabling self-employment.

loans.use: to purchase more poultry feed and chickens for resale.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 39 years old and married with six children between ten and 17 years old. His wife is a farmer and they live in their own semi-permanent house in Karuguza, Uganda. For the past 20 years, Vincent has been running a butcher shop. With the proceeds from his business, he has been able to buy land. Vincent’s goal for his family is to pay school fees and expand his business.

Vincent is requesting a loan to purchase cattle for his business. His major business challenge is inadequate capital. In the future, Vincent hopes his business will expand and he would like to own a ranch.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Pamella

texts.en:
Pamella N. lives in the Kanyanya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is in school. Pamella lives in a rented home without access to electricity or running water. Her major monthly expenses include food, rent, and school fees. For the past seven years, Pamella has run a business selling cosmetics. She works six days out of every week selling her products in a retail shop. 

Pamella is requesting a loan of 600,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy to buy more cosmetics and braids to sell. Her main business challenges are transportation, thieves, and seasonality. Pamella’s goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked shop and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and braids to sell

loans.name: Chrispus

texts.en: Chrispus M., a 39-year-old father of three married to Mariamu, a housewife, has been operating a retail shop in Mariakani for the last two years. This will be Chrispus’s first loan from KADET with which he plans to add stocks of bread, maize flour, wheat flour and soft drinks to his shop. He will direct the extra income generated from his business to the repayment of the loan. Chrispus’s dream is to expand his business.

loans.use: to add stocks of bread, maize flour, wheat flour and soft drinks

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 46 years old and a single mother of five children aged 14-27. She has no other dependents and her oldest son is a teacher. She lives in her own home with seven others in Karuguuza Uganda. For 20 years Grace has been operating a retail shop. With the proceeds she has been able to build a house and buy land. In the future she hopes her business will improve and grow into a wholesale operation. Grace intends to use the loan to buy sugar, salt and millet flour for sale.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, salt and millet flour for sale.

loans.name: Cissy

texts.en:
Cissy N. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Cissy has a business of a small hotel [restaurant], which she has had for less than one year.

To help expand her business, Cissy has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase food to cook for resale. With the help of this loan from BRAC, Cissy hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her young sister. In the future, Cissy hopes to go back to school and complete her studies. 

Cissy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase food to cook for resale.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is married and has one child who is not currently in school. Christine has a small beauty salon, which she has had for 2 years. She also has a second business selling soft drinks.

To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. This loan will be used to purchase braids, soda and splash for resale. With the help of this loan from BRAC, Christine hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food. In the future, Christine hopes to own a poultry firm. 

Christine is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save more money.

loans.use: to purchase braids, soda and splash for resale.

loans.name: Talie

texts.en:
Talie, a 37-year-old single man living in Chtoura, owns a grocery shop where he has been selling food products, cleaning products and toys since 2007. He enjoys a good reputation for the quality and price of his products and is requesting his first loan from Al Majmoua to buy new ones in order to keep meeting his customers’ needs.

Talie works hard on achieving customer satisfaction and hopes to open a new branch in the future. He also aspires to having a small family for whom he’ll be able to provide happiness and a healthy living.

loans.use: to buy new products.

loans.name: Kweterana Kakumiro Group

texts.en:
Edith is a hardworking 45-year-old married mother of seven children aged 9-26 years old. They live in Karuguuza Uganda. She is the leader of Kweterana Kakumiro group which is a group of hardworking mothers with a common goal. It should be noted that one of the members did not take a loan but as a group policy each member has to guarantee the other. 

She looks after her family since her husband is a peasant and they live in a 5-room semi-permanent house with four of their children. Her family goal is to be able to pay fees for her children's school. She has a retail shop which she has been running for 24 years. With the income she has been able to provide the basic needs for her family and pay school fees. 

However she faces a challenge of a high default rate of her debtors and she hopes in the future to upgrade her shop to a wholesale shop. Edith intends to use the credit to buy dry cereal, rice and groundnuts for sale.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil, soap and corn flour for sale.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Sarah has a business selling dry fish, which she has had for two years. She also has a second business of outside catering.

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase fish and cooking oil for making chapatti. With the help of this loan from BRAC, Sarah hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her young sisters. In the future, Sarah hopes to build a house.

Sarah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase fish and cooking oil for making chapatti.

loans.name: Zivamuntuyo Kyamujanju Group

texts.en: Isaac is 55 years old and married with eight children aged between 11-18 years old. They live in Karuguuza Uganda. He is the leader of Zivamuntuyo Kyamujanju Group which is a group of hardworking people who sweat to earn a living. Isaac’s wife operates a retail shop and they live in their own home with seven people. Their goal is to be self sustaining. For 25 years he has been running a business of bicycle spare parts and has been able to pay school fees, though he faces a challenge of many of his customers defaulting on their payments. Isaac needs a loan to buy more spare parts for sale.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for sale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose K. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is not currently in school. Rose runs a public pay phone, which she has had for 2 years. She also has a second business selling phone air time.

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. This loan will be used to purchase phone air time for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Rose hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, Rose hopes to own a small retail shop.

loans.use: to purchase phone air time for resale.

loans.name: Uheri Group

texts.fr: Kubuya B. Luendo est entrepreneur, vice présidente du groupe d’affaire de Trio « Uheri »,  âgée de 32 ans, mariée, mère de 6 enfants et tous fréquentent l’école. Son mari est un constructeur Maitre maçon. La cliente Kubuya B. Luendo est vendeuse des denrées alimentaires. Elle s’installe au long de la rue, au centre commercial Birere  parfois devant les grands dépôts, près de la mosquée Musulmane de Birere. Elle vient de réaliser 5 cycles opérationnels en bénéficiant de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec des nouveaux produits vers Kichanga dans le Masisis, ancien fief du chef rebelle du CNDP (2 sacs de haricots, 4 sacs de maïs, 4 sacs de sorgho, etc.).  En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise et construire une maison.  La cliente Kubuya B. Luendo remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique.
texts.en:
Kubuya B. Luendo is an entrepreneur, vice-president of the Trio « Uheri » group. She's 32 years old, married, and the mother of six children, who all attend school. Her husband is a master mason.

Kubuya B. Luendo sells food products. She finds a spot along the road, at the Birere commercial center, sometimes in front of large depots, or near the Birere muslim mosque.

She has completed her fifth loan cycle with Kiva's partner, MFI Hekima. She will use her new loan to buy new products in Kichanga in Masisis, former stronghold of the CNDP rebel's chief. She will buy 2 sacks of bean, 4 sacks of corn, 4 sacks or sorghum, etc. 

Furthermore, she ambitions to expand her business and build a house. Kubuya B. Luendo thanks Hekima for its actions in favor of the poor who are excluded from classical banks.

loans.use: to buy 2 sacks of bean, 4 sacks of corn, 4 sacks or sorghum, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Kyankyere Kwetungura Group, Kihihi

texts.en: B. Dickson is the leader of the Kyankyere Kwetungura group in Kihihi. He is 30 years old and married with four children aged 13, 11, 9, and 7. Dickson is a timber dealer transacting his business by the side of the road. He is able to generate 280,000UGX per month. He is also involved in selling bananas from which he generates another 100,000UGX monthly. He has been in the timber business for five years. Being hardworking and cooperative have enabled him grow. His dream is to be able expand his business and educate his children. He needs a loan to be able to buy trees for growing mor timber.

loans.use: To buy trees to grow more timber.

loans.name: Sokoroti Ole

texts.en:
Sokoroti Ole M., from Narok, Kenya, is 45 years old, married, and supports ten people in the family. He has been farming for the last 15 years.

Sokoroti first learned of KADET LTD through other registered clients in his area. This will be his fourth loan from KADET, and he intends to spend the loan to prepare the land for planting. He plans to reinvest the profit generated into the farm and dreams of being a big farmer. Sokoroti believes he can do more if provided with the necessary resources.

loans.use: to cultivate the land for next planting season.

loans.name: Yalley

texts.en:
Yalley, a 34-year old lady, lives in the Paynesville area. She’s married to a husband who works with the forestry development authority. She has four children between the ages of 7 months to 17 years. Two of them attend school while the others live with her sister.

In 2007 Yalley started a little business selling light bulbs, tissues, soap, beverages, etc. She really enjoys it since she earns more money for her family through the business.

Yalley is requesting a loan to purchase more toothpaste, drinks, light bulbs and other items for her business. She hopes to purchase a piece of land for her children in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more toothpaste, drinks, light bulbs and other items for resale.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret N. lives in the Mulago neighbourhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single with three children, all of whom are in school.  Margaret has a business selling fish. She has been in this business for ten years and works seven days every week. 

Margaret sells her products at the market. Margaret has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO. She will use the money to buy more baskets of fish. The main business challenges for Margaret include thieves and seasonality. 

Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own rooms for rent, and to start selling wholesale only. Margaret lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity, but not to running water. Her major monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of fish.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a married woman who lives in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato with her family. She is a rice farmer and raises pigs in her backyard for sale. Josephine works hard to increase her harvest and to keep the pigs healthy.

Josephine's loan will be used to purchase fertilizer and pig feed. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pig feed.

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en:
Cecelia is 49 years old and lives in the Paynesville Area. She’s a widow with four children between the ages of 16-34 years. Two of them live with her while the others are living on their own.

In 2008 she started a business selling soap, beverages, hardware and other items. She enjoys her business because customers purchase a lot of beverages.

Cecelia is requesting a loan to purchase cartoons of toothpaste, light bulbs, juice and other items.

She plans to open her own restaurant in the future.

loans.use: to purchase cartoons of toothpaste, light bulbs, juice and other items.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward N. is 33 years old, married and the father of two. His wife, Pola, is a business lady.
 
Edward runs a retail shop in Mariakani and he gets additional income from his motorcycle transport business. Edward has been in this business for the last three years.

This marks his first loan from KADET Ltd., and he plans to add more stock of sugar, cooking oil, maize flour and  wheat flour and to buy a dust board for his motorcycle. 

The anticipated profits will be directed into the repayment of the loan. Edward’s dream is to become a successful entrepreneur

loans.use: to add stock of sugar, cooking oil, maize flour and wheat flour and to buy a dust board for his motorcycle.

loans.name: Johnny

texts.en:
Johnny is a 46-year-old man who lives in Paynesville. He is married with three children between the ages of 12-23. One of them attends school.
Johnny started his business selling cement five years ago and makes a lot of profit during the dry season.

He’s requesting a loan to purchase more bags of cement for his business. He plans to expand his business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more bags of cement for his business.

loans.name: Twisungane Group

texts.fr: Theobard Sinzabwakwira est agriculteur de riz dans le secteur du Ruhuha, membre du groupe Twisungane, et client d’ACB depuis 2010.  Il a 65 ans, il est marie, et il a 8 enfants entre 21 ans et 42 ans.  Il est ne au Rwanda, dans le secteur de Ruhuha, et il a fini 3 ans d’école primaire.  Ce crédit est son troisième cycle avec ACB, et il a une très bonne histoire de remboursement.  Il va utiliser son prêt pour l’achat d’urée, NPK, et main d’œuvre pour son activité d’agriculture de riz.  Il voudrait devenir grossiste ou fournisseur de riz dans le secteur de Ruhuha, payer des frais médicaux pour sa famille, et aussi acheter une parcelle pour sa famille.
texts.en:
Theoberd Sinzabwakwira is a rice cultivator in Ruhuha sector, a member of Twisungane, and has been a customer of Kiva's partner, ACB, since 2010. He's 65 years old, married, and has eight children, age 21 to 42. He was born in Rwanda, in Ruhuha sector, and attended elementary school for three years.

He's seeking his third loan from ACB, and his repayment history is very good. He will use his loan to purchase urea and NPK fertilizers, and pay for labour  for his rice cultivation business. He would like to become a wholesaler or furnisher in Ruhuha sector, pay his family's medical expenses, and also buy a lot of land for his family.

loans.use: to purchase urea and NPK fertilizers, and pay for labour  for his rice cultivation business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a stainless steel table.

loans.name: Mary Nanette

texts.en:
Mary Nanette is 34 years old and has a one-year-old child. She has been in the business of hog-raising for eight years. She usually earns 3,000 PHP from farming. Mary Nanette also sells fish and sausages to the people in her neighborhood. She works hard to augment her family's income.

Mary Nanette will use this loan to purchase additional piglets and feed, and also more fish to resell. She hopes to have a stable source of income.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets, feed and fish.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fruits to make pulp.

loans.name: Nelsa

texts.en: Nelsa is a young entrepreneur who lives in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She makes a living by running a farm which her parents gave her. Her main crop is rice, but she also runs a sari-sari (or variety) store where she sells items such as canned goods, noodles and soap. Nelsa works hard to improve her farm and increase her income, and has applied for this loan to buy rice seeds, fertilizers and new items to sell in her store.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds, fertilizers and items to sell in a sari-sari store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy maize and bean seedlings and  fertilizer

loans.name: Newmee

texts.en: Newmee M. is 32 years old, married, and has one child. She is engaged in farming with her husband and hog-raising. Rice is the primary crop that they grow. Newmee also raises pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them in the market. Newmee is requesting a loan, which she will use to purchase pig feeds, rice seeds, and fertilizers.

loans.use: to purchase pig feeds, rice seeds, and fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bed sheets, comforters, and women's and men's clothing

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence N. lives in the Kamwokya Kifumbira section of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has three children, all of whom are in school.  For the last 10 years, she has made a living by selling fish, and works seven days a week. She sells her fish in the local market and has applied for this loan for 40,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more fish to sell, as well as bananas, beef, potatoes and rice. She supplements her income by renting out a motorcycle she owns. Her main challenges are the seasonal nature of her business and occasional thefts. In the future, she would like to open a restaurant and a business where she call sell items in retail markets. Florence owns the home she lives in and has access to electricity but no piped-in water. Her biggest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: to buy fish and other food items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Leonel Antonio

texts.es:
Leonel O. es un agricultor que ha dedicado su vida a la siembra de maíz, fríjol y café, sin embargo el invierno de la zona le ha generado algunos problemas por los que ha tenido que optar por la cría de animales como pollos y cerdos para complementar su trabajo en la agricultura.
 
Leonel aprendió este oficio de sus padres y desde los diez años está trabajando en este sector. Con sus cosechas a sacado a su familia a adelante y por eso está buscando el capital necesario para la compra de cuido de engorde para sus animales y fumigantes para evitar las plagas en sus cultivos. Esto le permitirá mejorar su producción y por consiguiente su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Leonel O. is a farmer who has dedicated his life to growing corn, beans and coffee. However, the winter season in his area has caused some problems, leading him to decide to raise animals such as chickens and pigs to complement his other agricultural work. 
 
Leonel learned this profession from his parents, and he has been working in this sector for ten years. With his harvests, he has helped his family get ahead, and for this reason he is seeking the capital he needs to buy supplies to fatten up his animals, as well as fumigation supplies to avoid pests and diseases in his crops. This will permit him to improve his production and, as a consequence, his quality of life.

loans.use: to buy supplies for his chickens and pigs and for his crops.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia, 44, is a married woman with seven children. Her oldest child is 24 years old and the youngest is eight. 

Ofelia is engaged in the business of hog-raising. She has a small backyard piggery that she hopes to expand. Ofelia sells her grown pigs to the market. She also wants to grow cows and carabaos. She plans to use her loan to purchase piglets, a cow and carabao.

loans.use: to purchase piglets, a cow, and carabao

loans.name: Renita

texts.en:
Renita is a farmer who lives in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato with her family. Her husband is also a farmer and driver. 

According to Renita, she and her husband has been growing rice for 28 years. Recently, they have been earning approximately 3900 Philippine pesos (PHP) per month. Her husband also earns extra money from driving. Renita does her best to improve their family's income. 

She requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes for this loan to help improve their harvest.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is a married woman with five children. Her oldest child is 22 years old and the youngest is four. 

Rosalinda is a farmer. She has been growing rice for 18 years. Each month, she earns 5500 Philippine pesos (PHP) from doing this farming. She has requested a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase rice seeds, fertilizer, and other farm inputs. 

In the future, Rosalinda hopes for her children to finish college and have bright futures. She also hopes for her business to grow.

loans.use: to purchase rice seeds, fertilizer, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Twigarukire Group

texts.fr:
Rénovât S.  est un commerçant âgé de 50ans qui habite la localité de Bwoga en Commune Gitega au centre du Burundi. Il fait le commerce de souliers depuis 4ans alors qu’il vendait les bidons vides et seaux, avant de commencer cette activité. Il est marie a Suavis N.,une cultivatrice et ont ensemble 6 enfants qui sont tous a l’école. Il n’a pas fréquente l’école.
 
Il demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter son capital en achetant de  grandes quantités de souliers à revendre pour réaliser de grands bénéfices. Il espère que son business va croitre considérablement pour être un grand commerçant.  

Il est membre  du groupe  Communautaire« Twigarukire».
texts.en:
Rénovât S. is a member of the Twigarukire community group. He is a 50-year-old merchant who lives in the Bwoga district of the town of Gitega, in central Burundi. He has been selling shoes for four years. Prior to this activity, he used to sell empty cans and buckets. He is married to Suavis N., a farmer, and together they have six children who all attend school. Rénovât did not go to school.

He is seeking financial support with Kiva to increase his working capital by purchasing large quantities of shoes to sell and make substantial profits. He wants his business to grow considerably so that he may become a great businessman.

loans.use: to increase his working capital by purchasing large quantities of shoes for resale

loans.name: Querubín De Jesús

texts.es:
Querubín S. trabaja desde hace 8 años como productor y comercializador de escobas y traperos. Comenzó con este oficio desde hace ya vario tiempo gracias a las enseñanzas de su hijo mayor quien estuvo en un centro de rehabilitación y dentro de su proceso de reinserción a la sociedad, aprendió técnicas para la elaboración de este implemento de limpieza.
 
Para poder fabricar las escobas, Querubín debe comprar más insumos teniendo en cuenta que si hace compras al por mayor puede reducir costos, es por esto que necesita un capital adicional que le permita obtener más materias primas. Este hombre, que sacó a sus hijos adelante él solo después de haber quedado viudo, sueña cada día con hacer crecer su microempresa para poder ayudar a otros.
texts.en:
Querubín has been working for 8 years as a producer and marketer of brooms. He started in this trade some time ago thanks to instruction from his oldest son who was in a rehabilitation center and, as part of his training for reintegration into society, learned techniques for making this cleaning tool.
In order to make the brooms, Querubín must buy more materials, keeping in mind that if he buys in bulk he can reduce his costs. This is why he needs some additional capital that will enable him to buy more raw materials. This man, who raised his children alone after he became a widower, dreams every day of growing his micro-enterprise in order to be able to help others.

loans.use: to purchase material to make brooms and mops

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma is 59 years old and married. She lives in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato with her family.

Wilma is engaged in farming. She helps her husband grow rice at their farm. She also grows pigs in their backyard. She sells the pigs to the market.

Wilma has requested a loan to purchase farm inputs. She also plans to use it in buying piglets, chickens, and ducks to grow.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs, piglets, chickens, and ducks

loans.name: Sasagara Group

texts.fr:
Pascasie N.  est une  commerçante âgée de 45ans qui habite la localité de Mumuri en Commune Makebuko de la Province de Gitega au centre du Burundi. Elle fait le commerce de produits alimentaires comme les bananes, la farine et le haricot depuis bientôt 3ans alors qu’elle était cultivatrice avant de commencer ce métier. Elle n’a pas fréquente l’école et est mère de 7 enfants dont 4 maries et les 3 autres sont des fonctionnaires. Son mari, Libérât Ndorere, fait le commerce des produits alimentaires. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter son capital en achetant de  grandes quantités de produits alimentaires à revendre pour réaliser de grands bénéfices. Elle souhaite être une grande commerçante pouvant fournir de grandes quantités de produits d’alimentation. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  Communautaire« Sasagara».
texts.en:
Pascasie N.   is a 45 year old merchant who lives at Mumuri in the commune of Makebuko situated in the Gitega Province of central Burundi. She has been selling food products such as bananas, flour and beans for nearly 3 years whereas previously she was a farmer. She did not go to school and she is the mother of 7 children of whom 4 are married and the other 3 are civil servants. Her husband, Libérât Ndorere, also sells food products.

She requests a Kiva loan in order to increase her capital by buying large quantities of food products for resale to make large profits. She hopes to become an important trader capable of supplying big quantities of food products.

She is a member of the « Sasagara» community group.

loans.use: increase her capital  by buying large quantities of food products for resale  to make large profits.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. lives in the Kamwokya Kifumbira neighbourhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school. 

Mary has a business of selling and making a local brew. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Mary sells her products from home. She has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy to buy more millet flour, cassava flour and maize bran. 

She also generates additional income through plaiting ladies hair. The main business challenges for Mary include thieves and seasonality. Her goal for her business is to start selling at wholesale only and also to buy a plot of land. Mary lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and  piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, food, and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bags of millet flour, maize bran and cassava flour

loans.name: Garukirabakenyezi Group

texts.fr:
Denise C.  est une  commerçante âgée de 48ans qui habite la localité de Bwoga en Commune Gitega au centre du Burundi. Elle fait le commerce de bananes depuis 4ans, le métier qu’elle commence  alors qu’elle était cultivatrice. Elle n’a pas fréquente l’école et est mère de 9 enfants dont 3 d’entre eux sont à l’école. Son mari, Datus N., est lui aussi commerçant de détail au Marché Central de la Ville de Gitega. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter son capital en achetant de  grandes quantités de produits alimentaires à revendre pour réaliser de grands bénéfices. Elle souhaite être une grande commerçante pouvant fournir de grandes quantités de produits d’alimentation. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  Communautaire« Garukirabakenyezi»et arrive au 16e cycle dans ce groupe.
texts.en:
Denise C. is a 48-year-old merchant who lives in the town of Bwoga in Commune Gitega, in central Burundi. She has been doing commerce in bananas for four years. It is a trade she began when she was a farmer. She did not attend school and is the mother of nine children, three of whom are in school. Her husband, Datus N., is also a retail merchant at the Central Market of Gitega City.

Denise is asking for a Kiva loan to increase her capital by buying large quantities of food items to resell, so as to make a big profit. She would like to be a major merchant able to provide large quantities of food.

She is a member of the community group “Garukirabakenyezi” and is now on her 16th [loan] cycle in this group.

loans.use: to increase her capital by buying large amounts of food to resell

loans.name: Tambuka Group

texts.fr:
Elisabeth N.  est une  commerçante âgée de 40ans qui habite la localité de Mumuri en Commune Makebuko de la Province de Gitega au centre du Burundi. Elle fait le commerce de bananes depuis 3ans alors qu’elle était cultivatrice avant de commencer ce métier. Elle a fait ses études primaires jusqu’en 6e année. Elle est une veuve et a 5 enfants qui étudient tous. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter son capital en achetant de  grandes quantités de bananes à revendre pour réaliser de grands bénéfices. Elle est très optimiste quant à l’avancement de son business et espère réussir sa vie familiale avec le succès de ses enfants. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  Communautaire« Tambuka».
texts.en:
Elisabeth N., 40, is a businesswoman who lives in Mumuri in the township of Makebuko, Province of Gitega, in central Burundi. She has been selling bananas for three years and before beginning this activity, she was a farmer. She went to school up through 6th grade. She is a widow with five children who are all enrolled in school.   

She has requested a loan from Kiva to grow her working capital by buying large quantities of bananas for resale so as to make more profit. She is very optimistic about the boost for her business and hopes to succeed in her family life as her children manage to succeed. 

She is a member of a borrowing group called "Tambuka".

loans.use: to buy large quantities of bananas for resale.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en: Annet S. lives in the Kalerwe neighbourhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has four children, all of whom attend school.   Annet has a business of selling bananas.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days a week. Annet    sells her products from home by means of retail.  Annet is requesting a loan for 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy to buy more bunches of bananas.  The main business challenges for Annet include thieves and seasonality.  Her goal for her business is to start selling on wholesale only.  She would also buy a plot of land.   Annet lives in a home, which she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, food, and school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Nderagakura Group

texts.fr:
Goreth M.  est une  commerçante âgée de 51ans qui habite la localité de Bwoga en Commune Gitega au centre du Burundi. Elle fait le commerce de produits alimentaires comme la farine, les tomates et les bananes depuis 7ans, le métier qu’elle commence  alors qu’elle était cultivatrice. Elle n’a pas fréquente l’école et est mère de 6 enfants dont 5 qui sont maries et 1 autre qui reste a l’école. Son mari, Emmanuel N., est un macon.
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter son capital en achetant de  grandes quantités de produits alimentaires à revendre pour réaliser de grands bénéfices. Elle fonde ses espoirs de vivre sur ce métier.

Elle est membre  du groupe  Communautaire« Nderagakura».
texts.en:
Goreth M., 51, is a businesswoman who lives in the village of Bwoga, in the township of Gitega, in central Burundi. She has been selling foodstuffs such as flour, tomatoes and bananas for seven years; she began back when she was a farmer. She did not get to go to school and is the mother of six children, of whom five are married and the other is still enrolled in school. Her husband, Emmanuel N., is a mason.

She is requesting a Kiva loan to add to her capital by buying larger quantities of foodstuffs for resale so as to make more profit. All her hopes for her life depend on this activity. 

She is a member of the community borrowing group called « Nderagakura».

loans.use: to buy large quantities of foodstuffs for resale.

loans.name: Biyinzika Group,bulenga-Kampala

texts.en: Ronald N. is 45 years old, married, and has four children, all of whom attend school.  He is a stickler for diligence and hard work, which have positively impacted not only on his six-year clothing sales business but also his family's standards of living. He has given a new lease on life to his family with earnings from his clothing sales business, which he operates in Bulenga, a growing suburb in the metropolis of Kampala. To get established in this business, Ronald relied on a loan to purchase clothing. What has made his business grow successful is the fact that Ronald strives to bring in new bales of clothing to sell almost every week, which is popular with both his old clientele and his new clients. The future looks bright for Ronald and he says with this loan, his business will continue to imporve. At present, this business generates weekly profits of 120,000 shillings. He says with this loan, he is going to purchase more bales of clothes that he can resell and make additional profits.

loans.use: To purchase of more bales of clothes

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter K. B. is 34 years old, married, and has of three children.  They live in Tuiyo in the outskirts of Eldoret town. He sells fuel and paraffin in Tuiyo and has been in this business for two years now.  Peter's monthly income is 80,000 shillings.

Peter is requesting his second loan from KADET, which he will use to add stock to his business.  He will buy fuel for sale and will use the profits to pay school fees for his children. In the future, he wants to continue with his business and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy fuel

loans.name: Barnaba

texts.en:
Barnaba is 68 years old and married to Rebecca Rotich. They are blessed with three children, 16, 14 and 12 years old.  Barnaba is a livestock farmer in Mutwot and has been doing this work for a period of 15 years, earning  a monthly income of ksh 10,000.

He has requested a loan of KES. 25,000, his fourth loan after successfully repaying the previous loans.  He hopes to use the money to purchase one cow for his farm.  The profits will be used to educate his children.

He hopes that he will own a big dairy farm in the future.

loans.use: to purchase one cow

loans.name: Line

texts.en: Line N. lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has three children, all of whom attend school.  Line  has a dry cleaning business.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days a week. Line sells her products from home by means of retail.  Line is requesting a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy  more boxes of bar and powdered soap.  The main business challenges for Line include thieves and seasonality.  Her goal for her business is to hire two employees to help in washing clothes.   Line lives in a home, which she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, food, and school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more boxes of bar and powdered soap

loans.name: Zaum Adhiambo

texts.en:
Zaum Adhiambo K. is 42 years old and married  to Maurice.  They have three children.  Zaum operates a salon, which she has been doing for the last eight  years. 

She learned about KADET LTD through marketing done by the KADET staff within Narok Town. She has been a good client, and this is her third loan. She is planning to buy cosmetics, weaves, shampoo, and hair treatments. Her salon is situated on a strategic point in the town, and she hopes to use the profit from this loan to reinvest back into her business. 

Her hope is to become a great businesswoman. She is an energetic woman who is dedicated to her work and who can do more if supported financially.

loans.use: to improve the services by buying cosmetics, weaves, shampoo, and hair treatments

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
